In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.
Praise be to Allah who bestowed His favor upon us and guided us to Islam, and granted us success in following the Sunnah of His Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, supporting it, defending its sanctuary, and refuting those who oppose it or deviate from it. Blessings and peace be upon His Messenger who said: 'Adhere to my Sunnah and the Sunnah of the Rightly Guided Caliphs, hold fast to it,' and upon his family, his companions, and those who follow them in adopting it and preferring it over everything that opposes it.
To proceed: This is a concise treatise in refutation of the treatise of the virtuous Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi, which he named 'Al-Ta'aqub Al-Hathith 'ala man Ta'ana fi ma Sahha min al-Hadith' (The Intensive Commentary on He Who Impugned What is Authentic of Hadith) or 'Tahqiq al-Bayan fi Ithbat Subhat Ahl al-Iman' (Verification of the Clarification in Proving the Prayer Beads of the People of Faith)! In it, he commented - according to his claim - on three Hadiths I had discussed in some of my articles published successively in the flourishing 'Al-Tamaddun Al-Islami' magazine, under the title 'Weak and Fabricated Hadiths and Their Negative Impact on the Ummah.' In those articles, I judged the Hadith 'What a good reminder is the Subha (prayer beads)' to be fabricated, and the chains of the Hadiths of Safiyyah and Sa'd (may Allah be pleased with them) regarding glorifying Allah (Tasbih) using pebbles or date stones to be weak. The Sheikh claimed that the first Hadith is weak but not fabricated, and that the other two Hadiths are authentic! Based on that, he established the legitimacy of counting Dhikr (remembrance) with beads and carrying them, even making it a slogan of the people of faith!
Had his eminence held the view he did without attacking us with arguments that contradict the science of Hadith and the terminologies established by the scholars, we would not have allowed ourselves to refute him, for he has the right to hold whatever view he wishes as long as he believes it to be legitimate, and refuting such opinions could be endless! However, since the Sheikh deviated in his refutation from those rules and contradicted them clearly, and even attributed to us what we did not say and do not believe before Allah, I saw that it was necessary to refute him and clarify his errors so that those who possess no knowledge are not deceived by them, and attribute to us what we did not say.

text:
We had published this refutation of ours in the aforementioned magazine in a series of articles, then we collected them in this treatise to facilitate reviewing them when needed, and so that whoever wishes may read them from those who did not see them in the magazine; may Allah reward those in charge of it with good. My hope is that the noble readers find in it a just refutation that does not compromise with anyone, nor attacks anyone unjustly, because the intention is to clarify the truth and facilitate the path to it, so that he whom Allah wills to guide may be guided. As for the one who turns away, refuses, is stubborn, and distances himself, there is no way to convince him even if you brought him every proof!
The readers will find in it - if Allah Almighty wills - a wonderful example of the practical method in applying branches to principles, whether in the principles of Hadith or Fiqh, and an explanation of our methodology in weakening Hadiths, and a verification of some Hadith rules that many of those occupied with the Sunnah, let alone others, have neglected! And a reminder of some fundamental rules that must be recalled and adopted by anyone who wishes to deem something good that did not exist before!
We have included in it some traditions (Athar) warning against innovation in religion, and we have drawn attention to some innovations that afflict those who have no knowledge of the Sunnah! And other benefits that the noble reader will encounter, if Allah Almighty wills.
I ask Allah, the Blessed and Exalted, to benefit my Muslim brothers with it, and to store its reward for us in the Hereafter. Praise be to Allah, and that is sufficient, and peace be upon His servants whom He has chosen.
Damascus: 22/11/1377
Abu Abdur-Rahman Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani

text:
Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
It is a collection of articles published successively in the illustrious magazine Al-Tamaddun Al-Islami
By Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani, Servant of the Sunnah
1377 AH - 1958 AD

In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful

Preface:
Damascus knew its greatest Muhaddith (scholar of Hadith), the erudite Sheikh Badr al-Din al-Hasani. When Allah took his soul, the lands became devoid of an Imam to whom eyes turned in the sciences of Hadith. However, an Albanian youth - (who grew up in an environment of knowledge and piety, and had a share of his name [Nasir al-Din = Supporter of Religion], Professor Muhammad Nasir al-Din) - became known among the youth for his service to Hadith and its sciences. He gathered the youth around him, became famous among them, and was able, through the eloquence of his Arabic tongue, the sweetness of his speech, and the quality of his debate, to attract an elite group that learned from him and became his students.
Since Hadith is the second source of Islamic jurisprudence after the Book of Allah, and relying on what is authentic according to the scholars of Hadith was a school of thought for the jurists, some supporters of Sheikh Nasir became famous for abandoning jurisprudential rulings in which they knew of a proven authentic Hadith [to the contrary], and some of them would stir up controversy. Hence, those who rallied against the Professor did so.
Finally, Sheikh Abdullah bin Muhammad from the family of Shaybah (custodians of the Kaaba) descended upon Damascus (he was born in Harar, Ethiopia, in the third generation of his family's migration). He memorizes ten thousand Hadiths of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, with their chains of transmission, and has a plentiful share of Shafi'i jurisprudence. His arrival in Damascus was to pursue books of Hadith and collect Quranic readings and similar services to the Sharia and its sciences.
A group of people of religion and knowledge saw in him a successor to Sheikh Badr al-Din, may Allah have mercy on him, so they sought his support against Sheikh Muhammad Nasir al-Din. A discussion took place between them in an atmosphere preceded by propaganda between the two parties, which caused Sheikh Abdullah to cut off the discussion before reaching the end of the round. Until, when Professor Al-Shaybi saw subsequent researches published by our magazine for Sheikh Muhammad Nasir al-Din regarding weak and fabricated Hadiths, he tracked what differed from his view regarding the Hadith of the 'Subha' (prayer beads), and sent us an article about that which we intended to publish. But soon after, he published a treatise titled 'Al-Ta'aqub Al-Hathith 'ala man Ta'ana fi ma Sahha min al-Hadith' (The Intensive Commentary on He Who Impugned What is Authentic of Hadith).

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
Since the policy of the magazine is to pave the way for spreading the truth and avoid, as much as possible, the field of futile give-and-take, and because we usually combine different viewpoints by presenting the arguments of both differing parties together, we presented this treatise to Sheikh Muhammad Nasir al-Din. He summarized what Professor Al-Shaybi brought, clarified the points of disagreement, and expounded during that on the rules of 'Jarh and Ta'dil' (Disparagement and Validation) with solid discussion that doubles the benefit for the readers. This is what the noble reader will see, and our goal is for the truth to become manifest for those who seek it, and Allah is behind the intention, and He guides the way.
* * *
Professor Sheikh Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani said:

The Point of Disagreement Between Me and the Sheikh:
The disagreement between me and the virtuous Sheikh Abdullah revolves around three Hadiths:
First: (What a good reminder is the Subha [prayer beads]).
Second: From Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas that he entered with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, upon a woman, and in front of her were date stones or pebbles with which she was glorifying Allah (Tasbih). So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: (Shall I tell you what is easier for you than this or better?) He said: (Glory be to Allah as many times as what He created in the heaven... the Hadith).
Third: From Safiyyah, she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, entered upon me while in front of me were four thousand date stones with which I was glorifying Allah... the Hadith, similar to the one before it.
In an article published by this noble magazine in parts (9 and 10, Year 22), I held the view that the first Hadith is weak in chain and fabricated in text; and that the other two Hadiths have weak chains, and that the mention of pebbles in the second one is Munkar (denounced) because it contradicts the authentic Hadith of Juwayriyah in Muslim which does not contain the mention of pebbles. (1)
As for his eminence the Sheikh, he held the view in his aforementioned treatise that the first Hadith is only weak and that the other two are authentic. In order for the intelligent reader to clarify the correct view from this disagreement, I must mention the principles upon which the Sheikh based his weakening and authentication, then return to answer them with what Allah, Glory be to Him and Exalted is He, facilitates.
foot_note: 1. (1) The article was printed with other articles on page (1/110/117).

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
The Principles Upon Which the Sheikh Based Weakening the Hadith Only:
The virtuous Sheikh established (p. 5 - 9) principles regarding the first Hadith:
First: That a Hadith is not judged as fabricated merely because the narrator is 'Munkar al-Hadith' (narrates denounced reports) or 'Majhul' (unknown); rather, both matters are causes of intermediate weakness.
Second: Nor is it judged as such merely because the narrator lies.
Third: Acting upon a severely weak Hadith is prevented - except the fabricated one - and it is that which is narrated uniquely by a liar or one accused of lying or one whose mistakes are excessive (p. 38).
Fourth: Among the indicators by which a fabricated Hadith is recognized is what is taken from the state of the narrated text, such as being contradictory to the text of the Quran, the Mutawatir Sunnah, the definitive Consensus, or explicit reason, where none of that accepts interpretation, as he quoted from Sheikh Ali al-Qari (p. 9).

The Answer to These Principles:
I say in answer to these principles in the previous order:
1 - This principle is correct and does not apply to me, because I did not judge the first Hadith as fabricated merely because there is an unknown narrator or one who narrates denounced reports among its narrators. Rather, it is because added to that is the fact that the Subha (prayer beads) is an innovation and contradicts the Sunnah of counting on the fingertips. My words in the 'referred article' are explicit in that, because I said after speaking about the men of the Hadith's chain (p. 201): 'So it is proven that it is a weak chain that cannot be used as proof.' The completion of this statement is: 'Then the Hadith, in terms of its meaning, is false to me for several reasons,' and the Sheikh quoted this (p. 12) without what came before it! But the Sheikh - may Allah forgive him - when he quoted my words in his treatise (p. 3 - 4) to refute them, quoted them abbreviating this important sentence from my speech, so he built his refutation against me without looking at it, falling into this exposed error due to which he attributed me (p. 5) to opposing the people of Hadith!
His eminence was not satisfied with blackening four pages on this principle about which there is no disagreement, but he returned at the end of the treatise (p. 29) and convened another chapter stating that anonymity and denouncement (Nakara) do not necessitate fabrication, then blackened another five pages to explain that. He would have been spared wasting time writing them had he contemplated my previous sentence...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...which explicitly states that the chain of the Hadith is weak! Had he done that, he would not have accused me by saying in this chapter (p. 41): 'In it is evidence to refute what this man claimed, that a narrator narrating denounced reports is proof that a Hadith is fabricated...'
I did not say this at all, O Sheikh, nor do I believe it. Rather, I believe the opposite. Here is the article in the 'Respected Magazine,' so on which page is this that you attribute to me?! By the grace of Allah Almighty, nearly twenty years have passed for me in studying the science of Noble Hadith, its principles and branches, while verifying it practically by returning branches to principles. So may my mother be bereft of me if I had claimed what you attribute to me! So a little deliberation and fairness, O virtuous Sheikh!

2 - The Sheikh's Error in Saying: 'A Hadith is Not Judged as Fabricated Due to the Lying of the Narrator'!
This principle is refuted by the saying of Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar in 'Sharh al-Nukhbah': 'Then the impugnment is either due to the lying of the narrator, or his being accused of it, or the excessiveness of his mistake or his negligence... The first: The Fabricated (Mawdu') - (Sheikh Ali al-Qari said in his commentary (p. 122 - 123): It is the impugnment due to the lying of the narrator) - and the judgment of it as fabrication is by way of dominant conjecture, not certainty. The second: The Discarded (Matruk),' Al-Qari said (p. 130): 'It is what is due to the narrator being accused of lying' - and the third: The Denounced (Munkar) according to one opinion.'
You see that Al-Hafiz made the description of the narrator as lying the highest level of disparagement, and made the Hadith of one in this rank 'Fabricated.' He made the one accused of lying in the second rank of disparagement, and made his Hadith 'Discarded,' which is the severely weak.
Look how his eminence the Sheikh confused the two ranks, making them one rank, and made the Hadith of the Liar (Fabricated) and the Accused of Lying (Discarded) in one rank, which is severe weakness!
What indicates his delusion is the saying of Imam Al-San'ani in 'Tawdih al-Afkar li Ma'ani Tanqih al-Anzar' (Vol 2, p 272) after mentioning the ranks of disparagement, including the first two ranks mentioned in Al-Hafiz's speech: 'And you do not say regarding the liar, i.e., the one they described as such, that he is accused of lying, because the first implies he is known for it, and the second implies negating that and that there is only a mere accusation against him.'

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
The Summary: The narration of a liar regarding a specific Hadith is sufficient to judge it as fabricated concerning this specific chain. This is the practice of critics in judging a Hadith as fabricated due to the narration of one of the liars, as Ibn al-Jawzi did in 'Al-Mawdu'at' and Al-Suyuti in his 'Dhayl' and 'La'ali' and others.
This does not contradict what the author quoted (p. 9) from Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi that 'the absolute lying of a narrator does not indicate fabrication,' because he means it does not indicate fabrication definitively (qatan) due to the possibility of his truthfulness [in that specific instance] and others following him. However, this does not negate judging it as fabricated by way of dominant conjecture (1) as previously quoted from Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar. Thus his statement aligns with the statement of his teacher Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi. Dominant conjecture is what most Sharia rulings are based upon, including what we are discussing. It is not permissible to abandon it except with a stronger proof, such as if a trustworthy man other than the liar narrates the Hadith narrated by the liar. In that case, this Hadith is used as proof, and we say that the truthfulness of this liar in this Hadith has become apparent to us due to his agreement with the trustworthy narrator, as indicated by his saying, peace and blessings be upon him, in the Hadith of the Jinn: 'He told you the truth though he is a liar'! However, in the absence of this trustworthy witness, the Hadith of the liar is fabricated without doubt. It has become clear to the reader from the foregoing who has 'opposed the science of Hadith'?!

3 - His Departure from the Method of Muhaddithin: regarding his statement that severely weak Hadith is what is uniquely narrated by a liar!
I do not know of anyone who preceded the author in describing the severely weak Hadith - (which has not reached the rank of 'Fabricated') - as that which is uniquely narrated by a liar! Rather, anyone who has smelled the scent of the science of Hadith does not doubt the (fabrication) of what is uniquely narrated by a liar. What prevents some from asserting its fabrication is the possibility that it has another path better than his path. But regarding the discussion of what is uniquely narrated by a liar, there is no doubt in its fabrication from the perspective of the terminology of Muhaddithin. The speech of Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar presented earlier is one of the clearest proofs of that. The discussion on the invalidity of this statement of the Sheikh is long, so we will not lengthen the article by mentioning it. It suffices in clarifying his error in that to say he equates the Hadith of one who is a liar with the Hadith of one who is truthful but makes excessive mistakes. This is something no one other than the Sheikh says! What scholars believe is that the Hadith of the liar is fabricated, and the Hadith of the one making excessive mistakes is very weak, as preceded. My prevailing thought is that the Sheikh came to this from what Al-Suyuti quoted in 'Al-Tadrib' (p. 108) from...
foot_note: 1. (1) See Sharh Nukhbat al-Fikar by Ali al-Qari (p. 123 - 124).

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
Al-Hafiz that he mentioned 'three conditions' for working with weak Hadith in virtuous deeds: 'First: That the weakness is not severe, thus excluding what is uniquely narrated by liars, those accused of lying, and those whose mistakes are excessive.' This is something accepted and known, while what the Sheikh mentioned is unknown and rejected.

4 - Verifying the Saying Regarding Indicators by Which the Fabricated is Recognized:
I say: These indicators which the Sheikh quoted from Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar are accepted. However, there is a subtlety in Al-Hafiz's speech here that must be noted, which is that his speech is not intended for the Hadith whose chain contains an accused person. Rather, it is specific to what has an apparently authentic chain that necessitates acting upon it, so it is then rejected by the contradiction mentioned in Al-Hafiz's speech. It cannot be applied to the Hadith narrated by a liar for reasons including:
First: That being from the narration of a liar drops it, and there is no need then to reject it by contradiction.
Second: Interpretation (Ta'wil) is a branch of authentication (Tashih). If the chain is fabricated, it spares us the burden of interpretation, as is not hidden. So it appears that Al-Hafiz's speech does not intend the Hadith whose chain cannot be used as proof.
The purpose of this is that I say the weak-chained Hadith is judged as fabricated by other indicators that may be lesser in strength than those mentioned previously. Among them is being contrary to the authentic Sunnah, even if it is not Mutawatir (consecutive). Supporting me in this is the saying of Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir in 'Ikhtisar Ulum al-Hadith' (p. 85) regarding mentioning the evidences of a fabricated Hadith: 'And from that is the weakness of its wording, the corruption of its meaning, or excessive exaggeration, or its contradiction to what is established in the Book and the authentic Sunnah.' Reflect on how he generalized the authentic Sunnah and did not restrict it to 'Mutawatir,' because his speech is more general than Al-Hafiz's speech, as appeared in this explanation.

The Fall of the Sheikh's Criticism of My Judgment of the Hadith as Fabricated:
Since our opinion regarding the four rules established by the virtuous Sheikh has become clear, and what is correct among them according to the Muhaddithin and what is not has been known, his criticism of me in my judgment of the Subha Hadith as fabricated remains invalid for two reasons:

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
First: That I weakened its chain, and the Sheikh agreed with me on weakening it from this aspect, and I did not judge it as fabricated because of it [the chain]. So his argument against me using the first rule falls.
Second: That I judged it as fabricated because the Subha is an innovation (Bid'ah), and because counting on it is contrary to the practical Sunnah, as I explained in the 'Article'. Thus, the Sheikh's saying (p. 13) falls, after quoting my speech judging it invalid: 'This invalidation of yours is invalid, for where does this apply to what they said regarding recognizing the fabricated? Which is what we presented from Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar that the report contradicts explicit reason.'
The reason for its fall is that Al-Hafiz's speech is focused on the authentic-chained Hadith if it is assumed to contradict explicit reason, as previously explained. Our Hadith here is not like that; rather it is weak. So judging it invalid is easier than judging an authentic-chained Hadith invalid, without doubt. And it is not a condition that it contradicts explicit reason; rather, it suffices that it contradicts the authentic Sunnah, for example, as indicated by Ibn Kathir's previous speech.

The Subha is an Innovation and Contrary to the Sunnah:
I had demonstrated in the 'Article' to which the Sheikh responded that the Subha is an innovation, and that glorifying Allah with it contradicts his guidance, peace and blessings be upon him, in glorifying with fingertips. I made these two matters indicators proving the invalidity and fabrication of the Hadith, but the Sheikh was not satisfied with that.
As for the first indicator, he rejected it with an exposed fallacy, which is his saying (p. 10): 'I wish I knew what intellect deems the existence of the Subha in the era of the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, definitively impossible.'
The face of the fallacy is that I did not claim the impossibility of the Subha's existence in that blessed era - rationally - because that is not among 'what is inconceivable in the mind to exist' definitively. The Subha is not among the theoretical issues whose possibility or impossibility is judged by reason. Rather, it is among the issues related to history, existence, and non-existence. If it is established among scholars that the Subha did not exist in his era, peace and blessings be upon him, but rather originated in the second century, then it is valid to denounce this Hadith considering that it encourages the Companions to something they do not know. This - meaning the encouragement - is irrational to emanate from him, peace and blessings be upon him, given the non-existence of the Subha. This indicates the fabrication of the Hadith and the fabricator's ignorance of the history of the Subha.

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
This is the basis of our judgment on the Hadith as invalid, not what the Sheikh portrayed as rational impossibility! It seems the virtuous Sheikh noticed this correct perspective, and therefore tried to answer it by saying (p. 10): 'Even if we assume its non-existence in that era, there is no rational impossibility in the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, encouraging his companions to something not known to them so they may act upon it when it exists...'.
Then he brought two examples for that:
First: The Hadith of Nabit al-Ashja'i raised [to the Prophet]: (Indeed, the most beloved of my nation to me are a people who come after me, believing in me while having not seen me, acting upon what is in the hanging pages) narrated by Ibn Asakir. The Sheikh mentioned a witness for it in the commentary from the Hadith of Umar via the narration of Al-Hakim.
Second: 'The Hadith of Abu Dawood from Al-Nawwas bin Sam'an: 'Jesus son of Mary will descend at the white minaret east of Damascus.'

The Weakness of the First Hadith and the Sheikh's Shortcoming in Referencing the Second! And an Explanation of their Lack of Indication for His Purpose!
The answer to the first example is from two aspects:
First: Not conceding its authenticity. For in the Hadith of Ibn Asakir there is a liar and another weak narrator. And in Al-Hakim's chain is a very weak narrator about whom Al-Bukhari said: 'Munkar al-Hadith' (Denounced in Hadith) (1), and Al-Nasa'i said: 'Not trustworthy.' Therefore, Al-Dhahabi rejected Al-Hakim's authentication of it. The Hadith has a third path better than the first two, but it is also weak. Detailed discussion on it will come, Allah willing, in the articles of 'Weak Hadiths' which clarify the weakness of many Hadiths thought to be authentic by some of the elite, let alone the general public!
The Second Aspect: That the Hadith, if authentic, is explicit that the 'hanging pages' - which is a metonymy for the Mus-hafs and books - were not in his era, peace and blessings be upon him. For he, peace and blessings be upon him, praises those who are not...
foot_note: 1. (1) Meaning it is not permissible to narrate from him, as Al-Suyuti mentioned in 'Al-Tadrib' (p. 127), noting that this is Al-Bukhari's intent with this phrase, and he accepted the validity of that from Al-Bukhari. As for the virtuous Sheikh, he indicated his view of its lack of validity by saying (p. 8): 'If true,' implying he did not trust Al-Suyuti's transmission. What is the reason for that, given that he was not alone in reporting it, but Al-Dhahabi preceded him in 'Al-Mizan' (1/5) quoting Ibn al-Qattan, and Al-Dhahabi relied upon it in his treatise 'Al-Muqizah'!!

text:
...his companions for their acting upon something that occurred after him, peace and blessings be upon him, believing in him in the unseen because of these Mus-hafs which they read and know his truthfulness, peace and blessings be upon him, through them. So there is not in the Hadith - if authentic - any encouragement for the Companions to act upon what they do not know. How could that be when they believe in him, memorize his Book, and know his biography?! This is contrary to the Hadith: (What a good reminder is the Subha), for there is not the slightest indication in it that he, peace and blessings be upon him, is encouraging his companions to something that will occur. Rather, what immediately comes to mind from it is only that he is encouraging them to use it while it is known to them. So the difference between it and the Hadith of (the Hanging Pages) appears (1), and thus the Sheikh's attempt to invalidate our judgment of the Hadith's invalidity falls.

Invalidating the Sheikh's Statement: 'The Companions Did Not Know the (Minaret)'!
As for the second example, which is the Hadith of the Minaret, the answer is: The author's use of it as evidence that he encouraged the Companions to act upon what they did not know in the present is one of the most amazing things in my view! This is for several reasons:
First: That the utmost the Hadith contains is information about the descent of Jesus, peace be upon him, at the Minaret, so there is no encouragement regarding it.
Second: From where does the author get that the meaning of 'Minaret' (Manara) in the Hadith is: The Muezzin's tower (Mi'dhanah) upon which the call to prayer is made, when there is nothing in the Hadith indicating that in the slightest? 'Al-Manara' in the language has other meanings: In 'Al-Qamus': 'Al-Manara is the place of light, like the lighthouse, the lamp-stand, and the minaret.' In 'Lisan al-Arab': 'Al-Manar is the plural of Manara, which is the sign placed between two boundaries.' So as long as 'Al-Manara' has multiple meanings, it is not permissible for us to specify one meaning from them except with evidence, which is missing here. Perhaps the Sheikh thinks this Minaret is the one east of the Umayyad Mosque which the common people call the Minaret of Jesus, peace be upon him! So the Sheikh restricted the Hadith to their understanding! This is rejected against him, especially since Al-Nawawi said in 'Sharh Muslim': 'This Minaret exists today east of Damascus.'

(1) Clarifying this difference is that everyone who reads or hears the Hadith (What a good reminder is the Subha) does not entertain in his mind anything but that he, peace and blessings be upon him, intends a Subha known in his era, not a Subha that will occur after him, unlike the Hadith of (the Hanging Pages). Since it is established that it did not exist in his era, peace and blessings be upon him, that indicates the invalidity of the Hadith, and this is a clear matter, and praise be to Allah for His success.

text:
He says: 'East of Damascus.' Had he understood the Hadith as the common people understand it, he would have said: 'East of the Umayyad Mosque.'
Third: Suppose the Hadith meant the 'Minaret' (Mi'dhanah), from where does the author get that the Companions did not know the Minaret?! Even though it is an Arabic word with a meaning understood by them?! He said in 'Al-Qamus': 'Al-Mi'dhanah is the place of Adhan, or the Manara (lighthouse/tower) and the Sawma'ah (hermitage).' This text from this Imam in explaining (Al-Mi'dhanah) implies that it also has multiple meanings, not a single meaning, so the objection we raised against the author regarding 'Al-Manara' applies here. If the first meaning is chosen for 'Al-Mi'dhanah', which is the place of Adhan, then this is something known to them, so it is not permissible to say they did not know it. If development has entered upon the Minaret in terms of construction, this does not remove it from its name which the Companions naturally knew. Since the Hadith informs about an unseen matter, it is not permissible for us to restrict the Minaret with attributes from ourselves without proof or evidence, then attribute to the Companions lack of knowledge of the Minaret!
The summary of the speech, O virtuous Sheikh, is that the Companions knew the Minaret well, but naturally they did not know the Minaret whose image formed in your mind, this image regarding which you can never say the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, intended in the Hadith. Based on this, your statement (p. 12): 'The Companions did not know the Minaret' is invalid.
If what we presented of these matters is established, the collapse of the author's deduction from the Hadith that he, peace and blessings be upon him, encouraged the Companions to act upon what they did not know becomes clear to the noble reader! And our statement that 'it is irrational for the Messenger, upon him be blessings and peace, to encourage his companions to a matter they do not know' remains free from opposition. Consequently, the first indicator of the invalidity of the Subha Hadith remains standing and correct (1).

Refuting the Sheikh's Saying that There is No Contradiction to the Sunnah in Glorifying with the Subha! And Detailed Speech on What counts as Opposition and What Does Not:
As for the second indicator, which is that glorifying with the Subha contradicts his guidance, peace and blessings be upon him, in glorifying with the fingertips, the virtuous Sheikh answered it by saying (p. 14 - 15):

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
"'It is said to you: Using beads instead of fingertips for Tasbih does not necessarily mean the doer opposes the guidance of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. Rather, the utmost implies that he left the better option, which is counting with the right hand because it is what was reported from his action, peace and blessings be upon him, and his saying.'
Then his eminence prolonged his speech mentioning analogues to this issue. If we wanted to track him in every example he cited, the article would become very long, and we would burden the magazine and the readers alike. But 'what cannot be completely grasped should not be completely left,' therefore I will say a comprehensive word regarding those examples:
The examples referred to are divided into two categories:
The first: Where the text indicates the permissibility of both matters and their virtue, and that one is better than the other. This is like what the Sheikh cited regarding praying voluntary prayers in mosques and homes. The text is his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: (The best prayer of a man is in his house except the obligatory prayer) narrated by Al-Bukhari and Muslim. A text from his action, peace and blessings be upon him, may stand in its place, which does not appear to the jurist to be better than his other action.
The other category: What the practical text from him, peace and blessings be upon him, came defining for an act of worship or restricting it with a description; then nothing came to indicate that opposing it is legitimate and has merit inferior to what he, peace and blessings be upon him, legislated by his action. Like performing Wudu with a Mudd and Ghusl with a Sa', for there is nothing in the Law indicating the legitimacy of exceeding it.
What we see and believe before Allah is: What falls into the first category, we prefer what he, peace and blessings be upon him, preferred, and we permit the other matter because the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, permitted it and assigned a virtue to it inferior to the virtue of the first matter, like praying voluntary prayers in mosques - not because we 'see people praying all Sunnah prayers in the mosque'!
As for what falls into the second category, we answer the Sheikh frankly: 'Yes, we denounce him just as we denounce the Subha due to his leaving what is reported from him, peace and blessings be upon him.' Imam Al-Bukhari said in the Book of Wudu from his Sahih (1/188 see Fath al-Bari): 'The people of knowledge disliked extravagance in it, and exceeding the action of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him.' It is not hidden that there is no difference between exceeding the number three or the amount of water, for all of it is exceeding the action of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. Supporting this is his saying, peace and blessings be upon him:

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
(There will be in this nation a people who transgress in purification and supplication) (1). Transgression is not permissible in Sharia, so it is proven that exceeding the amount of water defined by the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, in Wudu and Ghusl is not permissible. Thus falls from consideration the Sheikh's disapproving question in his saying: 'And most people today take for their Wudu much more than this amount, so do we make everyone who does not limit himself in his Wudu to a Mudd and in his Ghusl to a Sa' an opposer of his guidance, peace and blessings be upon him?!'!
How can one who exceeds his guidance, peace and blessings be upon him, not be an opposer, when there is nothing beyond his guidance, upon him be blessings and peace, except error? Therefore, the Shafi'is and others went to censuring extravagance in water in Wudu and Ghusl, and what Al-Bukhari quoted from the people of knowledge regarding the dislike of that has preceded. Indeed, some Shafi'is like Al-Baghawi and others went so far as to say it is forbidden (Haram) (2). This is closer to the apparent meaning of the Hadith of transgression in purification mentioned just now.
If these two categories of his worship, upon him be blessings and peace, have become clear to the noble readers, it is time to ask: Does glorifying with fingertips fall into the first category or the second? As for us, there is no doubt it is from the second category, 'because it is what was reported from his action, peace and blessings be upon him, and his saying,' as the virtuous Sheikh himself said! And nothing came from him, peace and blessings be upon him, indicating the legitimacy of opposing it and its virtue such that acting upon it would be permissible while leaving the best. The Sheikh's statement which we are refuting is explicit that glorifying with the Subha has virtue but glorifying with fingertips is better. Therefore, we demand from him the legal evidence for this virtue, and he has nothing but this Hadith (What a good reminder is the Subha), which is fabricated according to me, and weak according to the Sheikh, so it is not permissible to use it as proof in any case. As for analogizing the Subha to glorifying with pebbles, it is an analogy with a discrepancy, because the corruptions that usually arise from using the Subha, such as showing off (Riya') and being occupied by it from returning Salam as we pointed out in the 'Article', do not occur in glorifying with pebbles. Thus the measured and the measured upon differ. This is assuming the correctness of glorifying with pebbles from him, peace and blessings be upon him, which is not correct as we explained in the referred 'Article', and we will explain it further here, Allah willing.
It is strange of the Sheikh that he declares (p. 15) that counting with the right hand is 'what was reported from his action, peace and blessings be upon him, and his saying,' pointing by 'his saying' to the Hadith of Yusayrah raised [to the Prophet]:

(Hold fast to Tasbih, Tahlil, and Taqdis, and do not be negligent lest you forget Monotheism (Tawhid) - (and in a narration: Mercy) -, and count with the fingertips, for indeed they will be questioned and made to speak) (1).
This is a command to count with the fingertips, justified by the fact that they are (questioned and made to speak). So how does the Sheikh permit for himself, and for people, opposing this explicit command justified by this reason which dictates that nothing can take the place of counting, such as counting with beads or pebbles, due to the absence of the reason (Illah) in them!!
From the foregoing, it becomes clear to the insightful person that the Sheikh was unable to weaken the significance of the two previous indicators which I made evidences for the invalidity of the 'Subha' Hadith. Thus, they are safe from criticism and establish their indication most perfectly.

A Third Indicator of the Invalidity of the Subha Hadith:
Furthermore, I believe that what has passed is sufficient to convince the Sheikh of the invalidity of this Hadith in terms of its meaning. Nevertheless, I add to what preceded another indicator of invalidity, so I say:
It came in 'Lisan al-Arab' the following text: 'And (Al-Subha) are the beads with which the glorifier counts his Tasbih, and it is a post-classical (Muwallada) word.'
And in Sharh al-Qamus by Al-Zabidi: 'It is a post-classical word, said Al-Azhari. And our Sheikh said: It is not from the language in anything, and the Arabs did not know it. It only occurred in the first generation as an aid to Dhikr, a reminder, and an activation.'
It is established in the sciences of language and its literature that 'Al-Muwallad' is what was created by the Muwalladin whose words are not used as proof, and they are those who existed after the first generation (2). This indicates clearly that this Hadith (What a good reminder is the Subha) is fabricated after the first era because the word 'Subha' is not from his language, peace and blessings be upon him, nor from the language of his companions by the testimony of the people of...

2. See 'Al-Muzhir fi Ulum al-Lugha wa Anwa'iha' by Al-Suyuti (1/304) and 'Khizanat al-Adab' (1/4).

...knowledge of language. This is among the indicators Al-Hafiz pointed to by his saying: 'And among the indicators by which the Fabricated is recognized is what is taken from the state of the narrated text.' So it becomes clear that the 'Subha' is invented in essence and name, and that indicates the fabrication of this Hadith definitely, and Allah is the Granter of success.

Identifying the Fabricator of the Hadith:
If it is said: Then who is the fabricator of this Hadith? I say: I had mentioned in the 'Article' wherein I verified the saying regarding the fabrication of this Hadith the possibility that its flaw is Abdul-Samad bin Musa Al-Hashimi the weak one. Then it became clear to me now that the one accused of it is 'Muhammad bin Harun bin Isa bin Al-Mansur Al-Hashimi,' for he used to fabricate Hadith as will come. However, I had mentioned there that he is 'Muhammad bin Harun bin Al-Abbas bin Abi Ja'far Al-Mansur' and that he is of the people of cover and virtue, relying on the appearance of his lineage like this in Al-Khatib's biography of him, and I overlooked the biography after it which matches the lineage of the translator as appeared in the chain of the Hadith. Al-Khatib said: 'Muhammad bin Harun bin Isa bin Ibrahim bin Isa bin Abi Ja'far Al-Mansur, nicknamed Abu Ishaq and known as Ibn Buraynah... And in his Hadith are many denounced reports (Manakir), and Al-Daraqutni said: He is nothing.'
You see that the grandfather of Muhammad bin Harun the narrator of this Hadith is named 'Isa', and so he is in this biography, so it is him. As for the first biography, his grandfather's name is Al-Abbas, which contradicts his name in the Hadith's chain, so it is not him. Rather, it is this impugned one. Ibn Asakir accused him, saying as in 'Al-Lisan': 'He fabricates Hadith,' then he cited a Hadith for him and said! 'This is from his fabrications' (1). Likewise, Al-Khatib accused him, saying after the Hadith referred to (7/403):
foot_note: 1. (1) However, Al-Hafiz disputed Ibn Asakir that the referred Hadith is from the fabrications of this Al-Hashimi, because he was followed up on it. Then Al-Hafiz accused someone else of it. But the witness from Ibn Asakir's speech stands in any case due to his declaration that 'he fabricates Hadith' and that he has fabrications other than this.

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
"'And Al-Hashimi is known as Ibn Burayyah, his Hadith is gone (Dhahib al-Hadith), accused of fabrication.' So the suspicion of fabricating the Hadith is confined to him, and the responsibility of Abdul-Samad bin Musa is cleared of it despite his weakness and narration of denounced reports. The credit for my noticing this reality goes back to an old article of mine discussing this Hadith. So praise be to Allah for His success.

The Principles Upon Which the Sheikh Based the Authenticity of the Two Pebble Hadiths
After finishing establishing the principles upon which the Sheikh based his judgment of the Hadith as weak, and answering them with what returns upon him with refutation, I return to mention the principles upon which the Sheikh based his authentication of the two Hadiths, then I attack him with refutation, saying:
The Sheikh mentioned:
1 - 'The weakness of a text is not necessarily implied by the weakness of a chain, due to the possibility that it has another authentic chain, unless a Hafiz researches and his research leads to the judgment that nothing exists for it except this weak one. Then, the Hadith is judged weak due to the weakness of its chain' (p. 20).
2 - That an unknown narrator (Majhul), if one of the Imams of disparagement and validation validates him (Zakkah) along with the narration of one person from him, is accepted (p. 23), even if this validator is Ibn Hibban (p. 26).
3 - 'Gharabah (Strangeness) according to Al-Tirmidhi applies to several meanings that may coexist with correctness (Sahhah) as explained in the conclusion of Al-Jami' p. 27.'

The Answer to These Principles
Answering these three principles, I say:
1 - This rule is accepted if the Sheikh does not intend by it more than what he quoted from Al-Nawawi p. 21, which is his saying: 'If you see a Hadith with a weak chain, you have the right to say it is weak with this chain, but do not say it is weak in text merely due to the weakness of that chain unless an Imam says it was not narrated through an authentic path, or that it is weak while explaining its weakness.'
Clearer than that is the saying of Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi in the explanation of his Alfiyyah (1)
foot_note: 1. (1) His eminence the Sheikh quoted it in his handwritten treatise (p. 3) which is summarized from his printed treatise and contains few additions. I came across it after the Sheikh had printed its original and published it to the people! That is why I made my refutation on it because the handwritten one is part of it.

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
"'If you find a Hadith with a weak chain, you may say: This is weak, meaning the chain. You may not mean by that its absolute weakness based on the weakness of that path, for perhaps it has another authentic chain by which the Hadith is established. Rather, the permissibility of declaring its absolute weakness depends on the judgment of an Imam among the Imams of Hadith that it has no chain by which it is established, with that Imam describing the explanation of the aspect of weakness explicitly.'
Added to the above is the statement of Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar which the Sheikh cited following Al-Nawawi's previous statement: 'Likewise, if the statement of an Imam among the Imams of Hadith is found asserting that so-and-so was unique in narrating it, and the later scholar knows that the mentioned so-and-so has been weakened, then what prevents judging it as weak?!'

Permissibility of Weakening a Hadith restrictively or absolutely
We have benefited two things from these texts:
First: The permissibility of weakening a Hadith whose chain is weak, a weakening restricted to this chain, not absolutely, due to the possibility mentioned in Al-Iraqi's speech.
Second: It is permissible for the likes of us among the later scholars to weaken the Hadith absolutely based on the assertion of an Imam that one of the narrators was unique in it, and we have known his weakness.
If the noble reader contemplates these benefits, the prejudice of his eminence the Sheikh against me becomes clearly evident when he attributed to me (p. 20) opposing this rule and 'following personal desire'! While I never opposed the rule at all in all that I write of these 'Articles'; rather, my weakening of Hadiths revolves around it.
As for the first matter, it is apparent, and all scholars have proceeded upon this in their referencing (Takhrij) of Hadiths. If they find a Hadith with a weak chain, they say: 'Its chain is weak' or 'This is a weak Hadith' meaning its weakness regarding this specific chain. The possibility that it has another chain does not prevent them from that, because this possibility is not incumbent upon a person except from a theoretical perspective. As for the practical perspective, the Hadith with a weak chain is like the absolutely weak Hadith which scholars have declared weak and lacking another path.

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
Clarifying this for you is that his eminence the Sheikh stated - as preceded - that the Hadith 'What a good reminder is the Subha': 'is weak with this chain.' So we ask him: Do you treat this Hadith as an absolutely weak Hadith, so you do not permit using it as proof or asserting its attribution to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, or not? My predominant thought is that his answer will be affirmative, and that he treats it only as absolutely weak. Based on this, we ask him the second question: Is it possible that it has another chain or not? Predominant thought also suggests the answer will be affirmative. Then we say: Just as this possibility did not affect the weakness of your Hadith here, likewise it does not affect the weakness of the Hadiths I weaken due to the weakness of their chains. It would only affect that if you demonstrate my error in weakening them or my overlooking some of their authentic paths. But as for applying the mentioned possibility to them, no. Because it is impossible to imagine a Hadith weakened due to its chain without the mentioned possibility being applicable to it. If it were said that this possibility should be counted and considered a barrier to weakening the Hadith, reliance and trust in the sayings of scholars in weakening Hadiths would fall, and even in their authenticating authentic Hadiths, because it is possible, as some said, that some of their narrators erred or intentionally lied and this did not appear to the Muhaddithin! The corruption of this (saying) is not hidden from the intelligent observer.
As for the second matter, the absence of my opposition to the mentioned rule is clearer and more apparent, because our weakening in this case is based on the foundation of singularity (Tafarrud) asserted by some Imams. The two Hadiths we are discussing are among those Al-Tirmidhi declared some narrators were unique in narrating.
As for the first Hadith, which is the Hadith of Sa'd, Al-Tirmidhi said about it (4/278 Sharh al-Tuhfa): 'This is a Hasan Gharib Hadith from the Hadith of Sa'd.' This means it has no other chain from Sa'd. Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir said in 'Ikhtisar Ulum al-Hadith' in 'Knowledge of the Gharib' (p. 187): 'The Gharib is what is uniquely narrated by one person; he may be trustworthy, or he may be weak, and each has its ruling.'
I say: This Hadith is from the 'Weak' section because its narrator (Khuzaimah) is unknown (Majhul) as I mentioned there in the 'Article', and further explanation for it will come here.
As for the second Hadith, which is the Hadith of Safiyyah, Al-Tirmidhi also said (4/274):

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
"'We do not know it except from this aspect...' This is more explicit in indicating the uniqueness of one of its narrators in reporting it than his previous statement regarding the first Hadith, as is apparent. It is from the 'Weak' section as well due to the uniqueness of Hashim bin Sa'id Al-Kufi in narrating it, and he is weak as I mentioned there also. Al-Tirmidhi also weakened it by saying 'Gharib' and by saying: 'And its chain is not known (Ma'ruf).' So it is proven from this that my weakening of the two Hadiths is based on the rule of Hadith, not outside of it. Thus, what his eminence the Sheikh hummed about regarding it falls!

My Methodology in Weakening Hadiths:
Furthermore, when I weaken a Hadith, I do not restrict myself to weakening it merely because I saw this weak path for it. Rather, I pursue for that purpose everything my hand can reach of printed or manuscript [sources], seeking help in that from what the Imams and Hafizs said, all out of fear that it might have a path by which the proof is established, so I would fall into error by not being aware of it. I believe this methodology has been sensed by the noble readers in my articles 'Weak and Fabricated Hadiths,' for they often see in a single article of them repeated Hadiths with one meaning, each Hadith mentioned separately from the other with a serial number. This is only to apply this methodology and discuss the chain of each one of them in terms of weakening and disparagement, such that it is rare for anyone to correct me on a path I did not include! I do not believe Allah Almighty tasks us with more than this. Error is something no human is safe from, but he must exhaust his effort to reach the truth. If he hits the mark he has two rewards, and if he errs he has one reward. And Allah the Great spoke the truth: {Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity}.

Ibn Hibban's Authentication of the Unknown is Not Accepted:
2 - We quoted in the previous article the Sheikh's second rule, which is accepting the unknown narrator if one of the Imams of disparagement validates him. I say: This rule is not absolute; rather, it is restricted according to the verifying Muhaddithin to when the validator is not lenient in validation, like Imam Ahmad, Al-Bukhari, Abu Hatim, and others. But if he is known for leniency in that based on a rule of his in validation in which he opposed the Imams, then his validation of the unknown is not accepted, and the unknown does not exit anonymity by it! Among those lenient ones is Ibn Hibban Al-Busti, the author of 'Kitab al-Thiqat' (Book of Trustworthy Narrators).

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
For his school of thought in it is: 'That a man, if the anonymity of his person (Jahalat al-Ayn) is removed by the narration of one person from him, is just (Adl) until disparagement becomes apparent.' This is contrary to what is established in 'Mustalah al-Hadith' that his probity is not established by that, nor even by the narration of two just people from him. Therefore, Al-Nawawi said that 'his narration is not accepted according to the masses' (1). Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said in the introduction to 'Lisan al-Mizan' (p. 14) after relating Ibn Hibban's mentioned school: 'This is a strange school, and the majority are against it. This is Ibn Hibban's path in 'Kitab al-Thiqat' which he authored, for he mentions a multitude of those whom Abu Hatim and others explicitly stated were 'unknown'!' Then Al-Hafiz mentioned Al-Khatib's saying: 'Probity is not established by the narration of two.' Whoever wishes may verify it there.
This rule of Ibn Hibban is rarely noticed by those occupied with Hadith. Therefore, you see many of them validating a man merely due to Ibn Hibban's validation of him! While someone else might have explicitly stated his anonymity! As preceded from Al-Hafiz. Then these people build upon that the authentication of this validated person's Hadith! Thus appears the danger of ignorance regarding the basis of this rule and that it is rejected! Therefore, the verifiers among the scholars drew attention to it and warned against it. Al-Hafiz Muhammad bin Abdul-Hadi said in 'Al-Sarim al-Munaki' (p. 93): 'It is known that Ibn Hibban mentioned in this book which he compiled on trustworthy narrators a large number and a great multitude of unknown narrators whose conditions neither he nor anyone else knows! Ibn Hibban explicitly stated this in more than one place in this book. He said in the third layer:
1 - Sahl, narrates from Shaddad bin Al-Had, Abu Ya'qub narrated from him, and I do not know him, nor do I know who his father is!' Thus he mentioned this man in 'Kitab al-Thiqat' and stated explicitly that he does not know him.
He also said:
2 - 'Hanzalah, a sheikh who narrates Mursal reports, I do not know who he is, Ibn al-Mubarak narrated from him from Ibrahim bin Hanzalah from his father.'

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
3 - 'Al-Hasan Abu Abdullah, a sheikh who narrates Mursal reports, Ayyub Al-Najjar narrated from him, I do not know who he is nor whose son he is'!
He also said:
4 - Jamil, a sheikh who narrates from Abu Al-Malih bin Usama, Abdullah bin Awf narrated from him, I do not know who he is nor whose son he is.'
Ibn Hibban mentioned in this book a large multitude of this type. His method in it is that he mentions whoever he does not know with disparagement, even if he is unknown and his condition is not known. One should be aware of this, and know that Ibn Hibban's validation of a man merely by mentioning him in this book is of the lowest degrees of validation.'
Therefore, we see the verifiers among the scholars not validating those whom Ibn Hibban was unique in validating. Rather, they explicitly state their anonymity. Al-Dhahabi said in 'Al-Mizan': 'Ayyub from his father, from him Ka'b bin Sur, unknown.' Al-Hafiz said in 'Al-Lisan': 'And Ibn Hibban mentioned him in 'Al-Thiqat' and said: "Mahdi bin Maymun narrated from him, I do not know who he is, nor whose son he is"! This statement from Ibn Hibban supports what we went to, that he mentions in 'Kitab al-Thiqat' every unknown person from whom a trustworthy person narrated and who was not disparaged...'.
For this reason, we find hundreds of biographies in the book 'Tahdhib al-Tahdhib' by Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar where he mentioned that Ibn Hibban validated them, yet Al-Hafiz did not rely on him in his book 'Al-Taqrib'; rather, he said regarding each of them that he is unknown. Here are some of them for example:
1 - Aban bin Tariq Al-Qaysi.
2 - Bujayr bin Abi Yahya.
3 - Hatim bin Abi Nasr Al-Qinnasrini.
4 - Dubarah bin Abdullah Al-Hadrami.
5 - Tariq bin Abi Al-Hasna'.
6 - Abdullah bin Abi Bakr bin Zayd bin Al-Muhajir.
7 - Muhammad bin Habib Al-Jarmi.
8 - Al-Nu'man bin Ma'bad bin Hawdha Al-Ansari.
9 - Hisham bin Harun Al-Ansari.
10 - Yahya bin Abi Salih Al-Madani.

All of these and their likes in the hundreds, Al-Hafiz said in the biography of each of them 'Unknown' despite Ibn Hibban's validating them! These are decisive proofs that Ibn Hibban's validation is not relied upon by scholars, and that this rule mentioned by the virtuous Sheikh is not absolute even according to Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, to whom the Sheikh attributed its correctness! Let this be memorized, for it is very useful in the context of dispute, especially in what comes of our detailed refutation of the Sheikh.

Gharabah (Strangeness) according to Al-Tirmidhi does not coexist with correctness if he explicitly states weakness:
3 - We quoted from the Sheikh previously that Gharabah according to Al-Tirmidhi... may coexist with correctness. I say: This rule is also not correct absolutely; rather, it is restricted by constraints, the most important of which is if Al-Tirmidhi did not explicitly state the weakness of the Hadith he described as Gharib. Otherwise, in this case, it never coexists with correctness. Here are some examples from his Sunan:
1 - 'Gabriel came to me and said: O Muhammad, if you perform ablution, then sprinkle [water].' Al-Tirmidhi said (1/71): 'This is a Gharib Hadith, and I heard Muhammad (meaning Al-Bukhari) say Al-Hasan bin Ali Al-Hashimi is Munkar al-Hadith.'
2 - From Mu'adh bin Jabal who said: I saw the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, when he performed ablution, wiping his face with the edge of his garment. Al-Tirmidhi said (1/76): 'This is a Gharib Hadith, and its chain is weak.'
3 - From Ubayy bin Ka'b raised [to the Prophet]: 'Indeed, there is a devil for ablution called: Al-Walhan, so beware the whispering of water.' Al-Tirmidhi said (1/85): 'A Gharib Hadith and its chain is not strong.'
4 - From Ibn Abbas raised [to the Prophet]: 'Whoever calls the Adhan for seven years seeking reward, immunity from the Fire is written for him.' Al-Tirmidhi said (1/401):

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
"'A Gharib Hadith, and Jabir Al-Ju'fi (meaning the one in its chain) they weakened; Yahya ibn Sa'id and Abdul-Rahman bin Mahdi abandoned him.'
5 - From Ali bin Abi Talib raised [to the Prophet]: '...do not squat (Iq'a) between the two prostrations.' Al-Tirmidhi said (2/73): 'Gharib, we do not know it except from the Hadith of Abu Ishaq from Al-Harith from Ali, and the people of knowledge have weakened Al-Harith Al-A'war' (1).
Examples like this are very numerous in Sunan Al-Tirmidhi, and this amount suffices. From them, it becomes clear to the noble reader that the Gharabah mentioned in these five Hadiths and their likes cannot coexist with correctness at all due to Al-Tirmidhi's explicit statement in them of what contradicts correctness as preceded. Rather, Gharabah can coexist with correctness according to Al-Tirmidhi in some Hadiths which Al-Tirmidhi termed Gharib without explicitly stating their weakness or the weakness of their chains, such as the Hadith about which he said (2/57-58): 'Qutaybah narrated to us: Abdullah bin Nafi' narrated to us from Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Hasan from Abu Al-Zinad from Al-A'raj from Abu Hurayrah that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "When one of you goes to [prostrate], let him kneel in his prayer like the kneeling of a camel."' Al-Tirmidhi said: A Gharib Hadith, we do not know it from the Hadith of Abu Al-Zinad except from this aspect.
I say: This Hadith is authentic because its chain is authentic, its men are all trustworthy men of Muslim except...

What indicates the falsehood of his Hadith is the affirmation of the Iq'a (squatting) mentioned in it from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, in Sahih Muslim and others. So the supporters of the Sunnah and those who love it should do it sometimes in their prayer.

Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Hasan, who is known as Al-Nafs Al-Zakiyyah Al-Alawi, and he is trustworthy as Al-Hafiz and others said (1). This example is what can fall under the Sheikh's previous saying: 'Gharabah according to Al-Tirmidhi applies to several meanings that may coexist with correctness.' As for the aforementioned examples and what resembles them, they cannot be included in it. Thus the Sheikh's error appears in his absolute statement firstly, and in his usage and application of it to what is of the type of the five aforementioned examples secondly. An explanation of that will come, Allah willing, shortly.

Confronting the Three Principles with the Sheikh's Speech and Refuting It in Detail
To proceed, we have finished discussing the three principles upon which the virtuous Sheikh based his judgment of the authenticity of the two Hadiths of glorifying with pebbles. We have investigated the discussion on them and clarified our opinion regarding them sufficiently, if Allah Almighty wills, to reveal the truth. It is appropriate for us now to return to the two referred Hadiths and debate his eminence the Sheikh regarding what he held onto in authenticating them. So I say:

The Sheikh's Doubts in Authenticating Sa'd's Hadith and Their Refutation
As for Sa'd's Hadith, I had weakened it for two reasons:
First: The anonymity of one of its narrators: 'Khuzaimah', and I quoted it from Al-Dhahabi and Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar.
Second: The confusion (Ikhtilat) of Sa'id bin Abi Hilal', and I quoted it from Imam Ahmad.
foot_note: 1. (1) Benefit: The Hadith has been authenticated with a more complete wording from which it becomes clear that the 'kneeling of a camel' mentioned in it is what most worshippers do when going down for prostration! Which is placing their knees before their hands! For he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'If one of you prostrates, let him not kneel as the camel kneels, and let him place his hands before his knees.' Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Darimi, Al-Tahawi in his two books, Al-Daraqutni, and Al-Bayhaqi. Likewise Ahmad and Ibn Hazm, and its chain, Al-Nawawi and Al-Zarqani said is 'Good' (Jayyid). I have discussed the meaning of the Hadith briefly in my book: 'The Prophet's Prayer Described' Second Edition (p. 100 - 101). So the revivers of the Sunnah should love this Sunnah as well and not be deceived by what most people are upon!

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
The Sheikh rejected the first matter (p. 19 - 20) saying that Khuzaimah was mentioned by Ibn Hibban in 'Al-Thiqat' (The Trustworthy). He said: 'So he is trustworthy according to him.' And he rejected the second matter (p. 20) by saying: 'It suffices that the Six [Books] narrated from Ibn Abi Hilal'!
The answer to his first rejection is that Ibn Hibban's validation is not considered by scholars, as previously explained from scholars in the discussion on the second rule. Therefore, no one other than Ibn Hibban validated this Khuzaimah; rather Al-Dhahabi and Ibn Hajar said about him: 'Not known,' as I mentioned repeatedly. Thus this rejection of the Sheikh falls and collapses. It seems his eminence felt the weakness of his adherence to this validation, and therefore he said: 'So he is trustworthy according to him,' meaning according to Ibn Hibban. For this restriction 'according to him' has an implication if we consider it, so the Sheikh's phrase then implies that Khuzaimah is not trustworthy according to the Sheikh! But it appears he did not intend this implication, evidenced by his reliance on Ibn Hibban's validation and his rejection of my judgment on the anonymity of Kinanah, whose mention will come in the Hadith of Safiyyah; because Ibn Hibban validated him also as will come. Based on this, the Sheikh's saying: 'according to him' is meaningless speech! At that point I ask the virtuous Sheikh: How was it permissible for you to turn away from the speech of verifying scholars who clarified the weakness of Ibn Hibban's validation, such as Al-Dhahabi, Ibn Abdul-Hadi, Al-Asqalani, and others, and you remained holding onto Ibn Hibban's validation as if it were a considered validation?! If you have no knowledge of that, how was that hidden from you while you are in the process of supporting Hadith and its people?! And if it was not hidden from you, with what proof did you oppose these Imams? Then how is this hidden from you, while it appears you follow what I write in this noble magazine regarding clarifying weak Hadiths and my method in that, and I have mentioned repeatedly, sometimes in detail and sometimes briefly, my lack of reliance on Ibn Hibban's validation. So it was befitting of you, having known this opinion of mine, not to refute me with something that is neither from my school nor from the school of scholars before me. Rather, the duty which...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...scientific research requires is that you first clarify the corruption of this school which the referred scholars adhered to and which I followed them in, then build upon that the correctness of relying on Ibn Hibban's validation. If you did that, it would then be permissible for you to refute my judgment of a narrator's anonymity, following in that the critical scholars by your adherence to Ibn Hibban's validation of him. But you did not do that, and you will not find a way to do so!
As for the answer to his rejection of our weakening the Hadith due to the confusion of Ibn Abi Hilal by his previous saying: 'It suffices that the Six [Books] narrated from him...' I say: The answer is in two parts:
First: Concerning the authors of the four Sunan narrating from him. This is absolutely no proof, because it is known among those occupied with the science of Hadith that the four do not restrict themselves in these books of theirs to narrating from trustworthy narrators only. Rather, they also narrate from the weak, and from the discarded, and some of them from some liars as well! I do not think the Sheikh disputes this, so I will not prolong the speech on it.
Second: The Two Sheikhs [Bukhari and Muslim] narrating from him. This appears to be proof for the Sheikh, but it is not so for two reasons:
1 - It is possible that they narrated from him without being aware of what Imam Ahmad was aware of regarding his confusion. They are excused, indeed rewarded, for narrating from him. But this does not oblige us to turn away from Imam Ahmad's judgment of his confusion, for two reasons established in the science of principles (Usul): First: He who knows is a proof against he who does not know. Second: Disparagement takes precedence over validation. These rules, along with Ahmad's previous saying, all led me to weaken the Hadith due to Ibn Abi Hilal as well, even though I know he is among the men of the Two Sheikhs.
2 - It is possible that they narrated from him with knowledge of his confusion, and in that case, the presumption regarding them is that they did not narrate from him except what they knew was from his Hadith before his confusion. For among the confused narrators is a group whose Hadith before confusion the meticulous scholars of Hadith were able to distinguish from their Hadith after confusion. Perhaps this is understood by the Two Sheikhs. Ibn Al-Salah said in the Introduction to the Sciences of Hadith regarding knowing those trustworthy narrators who became confused at the end of their lives (p. 391 Aleppo Edition):

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
"'The ruling on them is that the Hadith of whoever took from them before confusion is accepted, and the Hadith of whoever took from them after confusion is not accepted, or if his matter is ambiguous and it is not known whether he took from him before confusion or after.' Then he said (p. 412): 'Know that whoever is of this category and his narration is relied upon in the Two Sahihs or one of them, we know in general that this is of what was distinguished and taken before confusion.' Al-Hafiz Burhan al-Din al-Halabi quoted it from him in the introduction to his treatise 'Al-Ightibat bi Ma'rifat man Rumiya bi al-Ikhtilat' then said (p. 3): 'And this is from the goodness of thought regarding them.' In the speech of these two Imams is clarification that among the men of the Two Sahihs is more than one of the confused narrators. So it is not permissible to exonerate them from confusion merely because they are among their men, just as it is not permissible to use their Hadith as proof except after verifying that it is from their Hadith before confusion. Look, O noble reader, how far the speech of his eminence the Sheikh is from correctness. He rejects my claim of Ibn Abi Hilal's confusion merely because he is among the men of the Two Sheikhs, while scholars say that among their men is more than one of the confused narrators! After establishing the confusion of this Ibn Abi Hilal and the lack of clarity regarding whether he narrated this Hadith before confusion, my weakening of this Hadith due to him remains standing, and the Sheikh's rejection of it is flimsy, indeed invalid.

The Sheikh's Distortion of Scholars' Speech and Accusing Me of Opposing Them!
Then the virtuous Sheikh - may Allah preserve him - wanted to supply us from his sciences, so he said in his treatise (p. 21) the following text: 'Then I increase you regarding the status of Sa'd's Hadith upon Al-Tirmidhi's grading of Hasan, the authentication of another besides him, namely Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar (Original: Bin Hajar - without the connecting Alif - and how many errors are in it despite its small size!)...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
in 'Amali al-Adhkar' and he mentioned that Ibn Hibban mentioned Khuzaimah in 'Al-Thiqat'. He said as in the commentary of Ibn Allan Al-Siddiqi after mentioning its extractors: A Sahih (authentic) Hadith.'
I say: It saddens me greatly to say: In this quotation from Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar there is much manipulation and disruptive abbreviation; which resembles Tadlis (deception) that drops its doer from the rank of those relied upon in what they narrate and quote. That is because everyone who comes across this speech quoted from Al-Hafiz, nothing comes to his mind except that the Hadith of Sa'd which contains the mention of date stones or pebbles is according to Al-Hafiz:
1 - Authentic in itself (Sahih li-Dhatihi).
2 - Authentic in its entirety, including the glorification with pebbles or date stones.
3 - That Khuzaimah who is in its chain is trustworthy according to him.
All of this is not implied by Al-Hafiz's speech at all when the noble reader stands upon it in its complete text as Ibn Allan mentioned it. He said in his 'Commentary on Al-Adhkar' the following text: 'Al-Hafiz said after mentioning who was mentioned among those who extracted it: A Sahih Hadith, and its men are men of the Sahih, except Khuzaimah, for his lineage and condition are not known, and no one narrated from him except Sa'id, meaning Ibn Abi Hilal. Ibn Hibban mentioned him in 'Al-Thiqat' as is his habit regarding one who was not disparaged and did not bring a denounced report. Al-Hakim authenticated it. The Hadith has a witness from the Hadith of Abu Umamah Al-Bahili that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, passed by him while he was moving his lips. He said: What are you saying O Abu Umamah? He said: I am remembering my Lord. He said: Shall I not tell you of what is more and better than that, night with day, and day with night? You say: Glory be to Allah the number of what Allah created, Glory be to Allah the fill of what Allah created, Glory be to Allah the number of what is in the earth and in the heaven, Glory be to Allah the number of what His Book recorded, Glory be to Allah the fill of what His Book recorded, Glory be to Allah the number of everything, Glory be to Allah the fill of everything, and you say: Praise be to Allah likewise. This is a Hasan Hadith, narrated by Al-Nasa'i in 'Al-Kubra'...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...and Ibn Hibban in 'Al-Du'a' from Al-Tabarani from two other aspects from Abu Umamah. End quote' (1).
This is the text of Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar's speech, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, which the virtuous Sheikh disrupted in his abbreviation, creating an illusion for the reader of what Al-Hafiz did not intend regarding the three issues mentioned shortly before. Rather, what his speech, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him, implies is the opposite. Namely:
1 - That the Hadith is only authentic due to others (Sahih li-Ghayrihi), not in itself. The difference between the two matters is clear because the Hadith authentic in itself is what is narrated by a precise just person from his like and the connection reaches the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and is not anomalous (Shadh) nor defective (Mu'allal). As for the Hadith authentic due to others, that is not required in it; rather, it is that which has a non-severe weakness in its chain, and has a witness like it or more that did not intensify in weakness. It may be Hasan in itself and rise to the degree of Sahih by a considered witness. This Hadith of Sa'd is only authentic due to others according to Ibn Hajar as implied by his previous speech. That is because after mentioning that it is an authentic Hadith and that its men are men of the Sahih, he excepted Khuzaimah from them and described him as one whose condition is not known, and no one narrated from him except Sa'id bin Abi Hilal. This is exactly what I said in my previous article explaining the weakness of this Hadith quoting Al-Dhahabi in 'Al-Mizan': 'Khuzaimah is not known, Sa'id bin Abi Hilal was unique in narrating from him.' Then I supported it with the statement of Al-Hafiz himself in 'Al-Taqrib': 'Not known.' So a Hadith containing one who is not known is inevitably weak, and it is inconceivable that a beginner in this science, let alone an Imam in it like Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, would authenticate its chain in itself. Thus it becomes clear that the Hadith according to him has a weak chain. If this is known, his saying 'the Hadith is authentic' means authentic due to others, and that is because of the witness he cited from the Hadith of Abu Umamah. It is a strong witness without doubt, but does it contain what witnesses to glorifying with pebbles which is the point of disagreement between me and the Sheikh? This is what you will see explained in the second issue, which is:

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
2 - It is not authentic in its entirety. You have learned from the foregoing that the Hadith's chain is not authentic according to Al-Hafiz, so the Hadith is consequently weak, unless a witness is found for it that attests to all the meanings and rulings contained within it. If you reconsider the witness with which Al-Hafiz strengthened the Hadith, you will not find in it glorifying with pebbles or date stones, namely the Hadith of Abu Umamah. Then it becomes clear to you that the Hadith is authentic regarding the multiplication of reward with such words mentioned in it. This is something I do not deny; rather, I indicated acknowledging it when I cited in the article referred to previously the authentic Hadith of Juwayriyah containing: 'Glory be to Allah and His praise, the number of His creation...' (1). Therefore, I did not include the original Hadith of Sa'd nor the Hadith of Safiyyah in 'Weak Hadiths' due to my belief in the reward mentioned in them in general. Rather, I cited them on the occasion of discussing the fabricated Hadith: 'What a good reminder is the Subha' and the connection existing between it and them regarding the mention of pebbles only. So I drew attention on this occasion to the weakness of their chains and the denouncement (Nakara) in one of them so that no one would use them as proof as the Sheikh did. The intention was not to direct towards clarifying the authenticity of the reward mentioned in them, especially since we mentioned there what suffices instead of them in this regard, namely the Hadith of Juwayriyah.
The summary of the speech on this issue is that the Hadith of Abu Umamah does not contain glorifying with pebbles or date stones, as is the case in the weak Hadith of Sa'd. Based on that, it should remain upon its weakness in this aspect due to its being devoid of a witness to mend its mentioned weakness. This is clear and not hidden from anyone with two eyes!
3 - Al-Hafiz's previous speech implied that Khuzaimah who is in the chain of Sa'd's Hadith is not trustworthy according to him, but unknown (Majhul) not known; even if Ibn Hibban validated him. I mentioned previously in the first issue what supports this from the speech of Al-Dhahabi, and indeed from the speech of Al-Hafiz himself in another source from his books, which is his book in which he stated that he judges the narrator with the most correct thing said about him...

(1) Perhaps this is what is meant by Al-Tirmidhi grading the Hadith Hasan, and Al-Hakim and others authenticating it, i.e., improving/validating what came in it of the mentioned multiplication. In that case, there is no disagreement between me and them, so it is not valid then to object to me with their words. Reflect fairly.

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...which is 'Al-Taqrib', specifically when described with expressions of varying ranks by the Imams of disparagement and validation, and he did not look in it to Ibn Hibban's mention in 'Al-Thiqat'. Thus the virtuous Sheikh said in his treatise (p. 20) while discussing the weakening of another man whom we might discuss when the occasion arises, Allah willing. Then he ignored all this regarding this Khuzaimah and did not pay attention to Ibn Hajar declaring him unknown in the mentioned book: 'Al-Taqrib' for a purpose in himself not hidden from the intelligent reader. He uses Ibn Hajar's judgment on a narrator as proof if it agrees with his opinion, and does not use it if it contradicts him! Would that this were due to Ijtihad from him and following the rules of Hadith, then we would have excused him, and said he is rewarded in any case. But he only does that following desire and partisanship for his opinion as witnessed by more than one place in this treatise. From that is his saying in it (p. 23): 'If it is said: What is the interpretation of Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar's authentication of Sa'd's Hadith in Al-Takhrij?
