I say: It is as if due to Ibn Hibban's validation of Khuzaimah along with narrating his Hadith in his Sahih, the anonymity of person and anonymity of condition were lifted from him according to him.'
I say: This interpretation is false, and its falsehood is not hidden from the Sheikh himself if he has an atom of knowledge. For how is it permissible for a knowledgeable person to interpret the scholar's speech with an interpretation that contradicts his explicit words? The mentioned interpretation means: That Khuzaimah is trustworthy according to Al-Hafiz, even though he explicitly stated that he is not known as I quoted from him repeatedly. If the Sheikh did not know this saying of Al-Hafiz, we might have excused him as well. But what does the fair person say about him knowing that the Sheikh has seen this saying evidenced by his quoting it from me in his treatise (p. 18 line 1) but he did not address it with an answer at all, as is his habit with every saying that is proof against him!
He is like some of those who claim reform in this era among the pseudo-jurists who view the schools of thought (and I do not say only the four) as multiple laws, taking from them what suits their various desires, or what solves their many problems according to their claim, without looking at the saying they chose from the perspective of legal evidence, but from the perspective of alleged interest only! And how can they know...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...interest and estimate it according to its proper value if they cannot distinguish between correct sayings and weak ones? Therefore, you see them agreeing with the Sunnah at times, and opposing it at other times, until they sometimes establish what no Muslim before them has said!
Likewise, we see the virtuous Sheikh selecting from the sayings of scholars, even a single scholar, what achieves his purpose which is refuting me! If he sees in some sayings of this scholar what contains proof for me, and a refutation of him (he turns away from it and distances himself)! As for looking at these sayings through the lens of rules established by scholars, accepting what agrees with them and leaving what contradicts them whether for him or against him, this is what he does not do; because he cannot. This is the assumption about him, and it is the lighter of the two matters! Otherwise, tell me by your Lord how does the Sheikh accept Al-Hafiz's saying in weakening a man and not accept it in weakening another man, were it not for desire or ignorance, may Allah protect us from both!
A line of poetry just came to mind suitable for the situation, but I saw it more appropriate not to mention it to maintain the scientific style in my refutation of the Sheikh, and to be polite with him, even if he has departed from this style in more than one place in this treatise and others (!) as is not hidden from one who reads it.
The summary of the speech on this issue is that Khuzaimah who is in the chain of the Pebble Hadith from the narration of Sa'd is unknown according to scholars, including Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar himself. Ibn Hibban's validation of him is not considered by them. Therefore, the mentioned Al-Hafiz did not rely on it. I have detailed the reason for scholars not considering Ibn Hibban's validation repeatedly, the last of which was in some previous articles of this refutation, so let whoever wishes refer to it.
Here is another thing that should be noted, which is that the Sheikh's interpretation of Ibn Hajar's authentication of the Hadith with the interpretation previously quoted from him, and whose invalidity we showed, is another proof from his eminence that he intended by quoting Al-Hafiz's speech in a disruptive abbreviated manner to delude the reader that Al-Hafiz authenticated the Hadith in itself, while he only authenticated it due to others. The difference between the two matters has been explained in the first issue, just as I clarified the fruit of this difference in the second issue, which is that the mention of pebbles and date stones in Sa'd's Hadith is weak.

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
Thus it becomes clear to the noble reader that Al-Hafiz's speech is for us, not against us, and that the virtuous Sheikh returned from it empty-handed! And Allah is the Granter of success, there is no god but Him.
With this verification, the truthfulness of the Sheikh in the first half of the judgment he pronounced on himself becomes clear to the intelligent reader by his saying (p. 21) after a useless discussion: 'This is explicit that someone like me and you does not have the function of authentication and weakening.' He was correct in his judgment on himself that he is not qualified for authentication and weakening, because a man knows himself better than others, and Allah the Great spoke the truth when He says {Rather, man, against himself, will be a witness}. In reality, his researches in this treatise and others (!) clearly indicate the correctness of this judgment he issued on himself! This alone is sufficient to eliminate what he went to regarding the authenticity of the Hadith containing Dhikr with pebbles or date stones, because by his own admission he is not qualified for authentication, so it is not accepted from him. If he argues with someone else's authentication of it, the answer is from two aspects:
First: That we have not found until now anyone who authenticated the chain of either of the two Hadiths, such that it would be valid to use all rulings contained in it as proof.
Second: That no one explicitly stated the establishment of the mention of pebbles in the Hadith, even a non-intrinsic establishment, meaning valid due to others. This is what we have not seen narrated from anyone whose authentication is trusted.
As for his judgment on others that they do not have the function of authentication and weakening, this is something the decision regarding it does not return to him, but to the people of knowledge specialized in this noble science! So this judgment has no importance!
From what preceded, the Sheikh's fallacy appears to the rational person in his saying (p. 22): 'So your opposition to Al-Tirmidhi's grading of Hasan, and Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar's authentication of it has become clear, and that your speech regarding it has no place of consideration by the judgment of the rules of the science of Hadith.'
The matter may need clarification, so I say, apologizing to the virtuous readers for the length:

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
As for the Sheikh's claim of my opposing Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar regarding Sa'd's Hadith, it is a false claim, because Ibn Hajar did not authenticate its chain but weakened it. He only authenticated the text of the Hadith due to the witness he mentioned from the Hadith of Abu Umamah, and it does not contain counting with pebbles which the Sheikh authenticates. So this portion of it remained upon its weakness. Detailed discussion on that has preceded, so there is no need to prolong it, the intention is only to alert. So where is their alleged opposition to Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar?!
As for my opposing Al-Tirmidhi's grading of Hasan, the answer is from two aspects:
First: That there is no harm on me if I oppose Al-Tirmidhi in some of his Hasan gradings, indeed in some of his authentications. That is because Al-Tirmidhi is known among scholars for his leniency in that, until Al-Hafiz Al-Dhahabi said: 'Therefore, scholars do not rely on Al-Tirmidhi's authentication.' What Al-Dhahabi said is sensed by the researcher in the sayings of scholars regarding the Hadiths they differed over. I have previously mentioned in my articles 'Weak and Fabricated Hadiths' many Hadiths that Al-Tirmidhi graded Hasan or Sahih while they are weak according to scholars due to the establishment of what scratches their establishment according to them, and that was hidden from Al-Tirmidhi {and above every person of knowledge is one more knowing}. So my opposing him, if established, is nothing except to one who knows the truth by men! Contrary to what is established among scholars that men are known by the truth, so know the truth and you will know the men.
Second: That the Sheikh's accusing me of opposing Al-Tirmidhi's grading of Hasan would only be valid if Al-Tirmidhi meant by his saying: 'Hasan Hadith' that its chain is Hasan in itself. Establishing this is like stripping thorns [impossible]. For Al-Tirmidhi defined the Hadith about which he says 'Hasan Hadith' in the conclusion of his book 'Al-Sunan' with what essentially means its chain is not Hasan in itself according to him, but...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...Hasan according to him due to its coming from another aspect (1). The text of his words regarding that was quoted by the virtuous Sheikh from some of my comments on page (19) of his treatise. So let his eminence reconsider it if he wishes to verify what we say, and it will appear to him clearly that he is quick to accuse, bold in doing so without right!
If this becomes clear to the noble reader, it appears to him that Al-Tirmidhi agrees with me that the Hadith's chain is weak. What remains is looking into Al-Tirmidhi's intent by his saying: 'Hasan Hadith'; does he mean that it is Hasan in all its meanings and the rulings contained in it? Or does he mean some of that? If he meant this second one, then there is absolutely no difference between me and him either, because I say the Hadith is authentic except for counting with pebbles as previously mentioned repeatedly. This is what is preponderant to me; because Al-Tirmidhi cited the Hadith in 'Chapter on the Prophet's Supplication (peace and blessings be upon him) and his seeking refuge at the end of every prayer'. Had he intended the first, he would have convened another chapter for it, as some later scholars did, such as 'Chapter on the Permissibility of Counting Tasbih with Date Stones and Similar Things', or at least he would have cited it in 'Chapter on What Came Regarding Counting Tasbih with the Hand' which he convened in his Sunan, and he would have pointed to it in the chapter by his saying: 'And counting it with date stones and similar things' as that aforementioned group did. But he did nothing of this at all. Rather, he limited himself to citing it in the previous chapter, and I do not oppose him in that as preceded. So whoever claims that counting with pebbles is established according to Al-Tirmidhi, the burden of proof is upon him. It is not permissible to cling to his saying: 'Hasan Hadith' during a dispute, due to the possibility that he does not mean by that...
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-Suyuti said in 'Al-Tadrib' (p. 50): 'Sheikh Al-Islam (meaning Ibn Hajar) said: Al-Tirmidhi distinguished the Hasan Hadith from the Sahih by two things: First, that its narrator falls short of the degree of the narrator of Sahih, indeed even the narrator of Hasan in itself, which is that he is not accused of lying. This includes the covered (Mastur) and unknown (Majhul) (I say: like this Hadith of Sa'd) and similar ones. The narrator of Sahih must be trustworthy, and the narrator of Hasan in itself must be described with precision, and being not accused is not sufficient. He said: Al-Tirmidhi did not deviate from saying 'Thiqat' (trustworthy ones), which is one word, to what he said except to intend the falling short of its narrator from the description of Trustworthy, as is the habit of the eloquent. Second: Its coming from more than one aspect.'

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...the Hadith in its entirety, but rather the portion of it related to the chapter, as previously explained. Supporting this also is Al-Tirmidhi's saying in completing his definition of the Hasan Hadith according to him: 'And it is narrated from other than one aspect similar to that (Nahwa dhalik), so it is according to us a Hasan Hadith.' His saying: 'Similar to that' is like a text stating that he does not mean it agrees with it in all its meanings, otherwise he would have said 'Like that' (Mithla dhalik). The difference between the two expressions is not hidden from a scholar, especially if he has knowledge of this noble science. Thus, what the Sheikh claimed of my opposing Al-Tirmidhi's grading of Hasan and Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar's authentication of Sa'd's Hadith falls by this verification. It is proven that each of them preceded me in stating the weakness of the Hadith's chain, the first implicitly and the other explicitly, and that the first's grading of Hasan and the other's authentication intended the text of the Hadith in general, not the chain, and that I do not oppose what is in that. And that the mention of date stones or pebbles in it is weak, due to the lack of what witnesses for it, except the Hadith of Safiyyah which is Munkar (denounced) as previously explained when discussing the first Hadith: 'What a good reminder is the Subha.' We increase it in clarification here, saying:

The Third Hadith
Then the virtuous Sheikh said (p. 23 - 24):
'Then you said the following text: Second: From Safiyyah, she said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, entered upon me while in front of me were four thousand date stones with which I was glorifying Allah. He said: O daughter of Huyayy, what is this? I said: I am glorifying with them. He said: I have glorified since I stood over your head more than this... Say: Glory be to Allah the number of what Allah created of things. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi (1) and Al-Hakim via the path of Hashim...
foot_note: 1. (1) The Sheikh said here in a comment: 'Your attributing this wording to Al-Tirmidhi is incorrect, for Al-Tirmidhi's wording is Glory be to Allah the number of His creation, so whoever wishes verification let him browse the original.' I say: I attributed the Hadith to Al-Hakim also as you see, and the wording belongs to him. Such commentary with what has no benefit, rather indicates the Sheikh's rush to criticize merely for the sake of criticism and rioting, not for benefit. Otherwise, what I did is what the practice of Muhaddithin proceeded upon, and were it not for lengthening, I would have brought dozens of examples for that. The alert person suffices with a signal.

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...bin Sa'id from Kinanah the freed slave of Safiyyah from her. Al-Tirmidhi weakened it by his saying: (This is a Gharib Hadith, we do not know it except from this aspect from the Hadith of Hashim bin Sa'id Al-Kufi, and its chain is not known. In the chapter is [a narration] from Ibn Abbas. As for Al-Hakim, he said: Authentic chain, and Al-Dhahabi agreed with him etc. End quote.
I say: The answer to this grading of Gharib by Al-Tirmidhi which appears to be weakening is that Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar (1) said in Takhrij al-Adhkar as in Ibn Allan's commentary (p. 45) (2) after referencing it via the path of Al-Tabarani 'A Hasan Hadith'. Al-Tirmidhi narrated it from Muhammad bin Bashar bin Bundar (3) from Abdul-Samad bin Abdul-Warith from Hashim bin Sa'id from Kinanah from Safiyyah, may Allah be pleased with her, and he is Madinan, five people narrated from him, and Ibn Hibban mentioned him in Al-Thiqat. End quote.
Do you have anything left to cling to after Al-Hafiz became aware of another path for it and graded it Hasan because of it, not because of Al-Tirmidhi's path?'
foot_note:
1. (1) Thus in the original dropping the connecting Hamza from 'Ibn'. A similar instance preceded for the Sheikh as I pointed out in my previous article, indicating it is not a typographical error the Sheikh neglected to correct!
2. Thus in the Sheikh's treatise, and this is an error from him not the printer because he repeated it as will come shortly. The correct is (1/245).
3. Thus in the Sheikh's treatise: 'bin Bundar', which is a clear error because 'Bundar' is not the grandfather of Muhammad bin Bashar but rather a nickname for him, and he is known by that among those who have knowledge of this noble science. Do not think, O reader, that this is a typographical error in the Sheikh's treatise - and how many like it are in it! - rather it is an error that occurred in 'Ibn Allan's Commentary' from which the virtuous Sheikh quoted this speech, so he fell into the error as well imitating the printer without knowing! This indicates to us that the Sheikh has no knowledge of the names of narrators and their nicknames. Another example supporting what I mentioned will come.

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
I say this is an admission by the Sheikh of the weakness of Al-Tirmidhi's chain for the Hadith, so that spares us the burden of researching it again. It also absolves us from answering what he quoted from Al-Hafiz regarding 'Kinanah, freed slave of Safiyyah' which creates the illusion that Kinanah is trustworthy according to Al-Hafiz. That is not the case; rather he is 'Maqbul' (Acceptable) according to him as I mentioned previously and the virtuous Sheikh in his treatise (p. 26). If he understands from this word 'Maqbul' meaning 'Trustworthy' or similar, then he is definitely mistaken. But we will not debate him on it nor on what he blackened page (25) of his treatise with speech regarding what I quoted from Al-Hafiz concerning the weakening of Hashim bin Sa'id. I say I will not debate him on all this now because it is futile after the Sheikh's admission of the weakness of the Hadith's chain which I weakened following Al-Tirmidhi. Let us look then at the other path for which Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar graded this Hadith Hasan.
The Sheikh said (p. 25) following what I quoted from him just now of Al-Hafiz's speech: 'Then he referenced it from the narration of Khudayj (1) bin Mu'awiyah from Kinanah from Safiyyah similarly and said in it "And it contained (Original: in it and was!) four thousand date stones; when she prayed the morning prayer she brought them and glorified after that." He said: And he narrated it in Al-Du'a from another aspect from Safiyyah. The rest of Al-Tirmidhi's men are men of the Sahih as in Sharh al-Adhkar by Ibn Allan (p. 45) (2).'
I say: In this speech of Al-Hafiz are two benefits:
First: That Hudayj bin Mu'awiyah followed up Hashim bin Sa'id the weak one, so the suspicion of...
foot_note:
1. (1) Thus in the Sheikh's treatise, which is one of his errors in which he imitated the printer of Sharh al-Adhkar by Ibn Allan! For this word appeared in it as the Sheikh quoted it 'Khudayj' and this is a misspelling (Tashif). The correct is 'Hudayj' with a Damma on the un-dotted Ha and Fatha on the un-dotted Dal then Jim. See the previous comment (p. 515). Hudayj is not used as proof; Ibn Ma'in, Al-Nasa'i and others weakened him.
2. This is from the Sheikh's writing errors. The correct is (1/245). See the comment on page (512).

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...his uniqueness is removed. I say: But the other defect remains in it, which is 'Kinanah'. You have known his condition from what we cited of scholars' sayings when discussing this Hadith in the context of explaining the fabrication of the Hadith 'What a good reminder is the Subha,' so refer to it if you wish.
Second: That the Hadith has another path from Safiyyah.
This benefit is what the Sheikh clung to when he boasted with his previous saying: 'Do we have anything left to cling to... etc.'
In answer to this I say: Yes, I still adhere to what I held regarding weakening the Hadith's chain; because the proof of its weakness still stands, and it is not permissible to leave it and turn away from it merely for the illusion of an imaginer! What you quoted from Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar does not imply more than that the Hadith is Hasan due to others. We have explained to you the difference between a Hadith being Hasan in itself and being Hasan due to others in what passed of the discussion on Sa'd's Hadith, so we will not repeat the speech on it. Also, I mentioned repeatedly that I do not deny the virtue of Dhikr mentioned in the Hadith because it appears in Juwayriyah's Hadith in Sahih Muslim. Rather, I denied and still deny counting Dhikr with pebbles or date stones due to its lack of establishment in the Hadith, and due to its contradicting the authentic Sunnah established from him, peace and blessings be upon him, of counting with fingertips. This other path which Al-Hafiz mentioned, he did not mention that the mention of pebbles or date stones occurred in it. It is possible that it is in it, and the opposite is possible. It is known that probability invalidates deduction in places of dispute and argument. So it is proven that you have no proof in the speech of Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him.
The summary of speech on this Hadith is that the Sheikh agrees with me on weakening it from the first path, but he argues for its strengthening by other paths imitating Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar. But the latter did not mention that the Hadith contains mention of pebbles. So it is not permissible to use his previous general speech as proof for this detailed matter. The Sheikh must - if he wishes - search for the wording of this path and see if this counting is in it. If it is established in it, and is free from what scratches the validity of using it as proof as is the apparent meaning of Al-Hafiz's speech, his claim is proven. Otherwise, without that is stripping thorns.

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
I clarified previously that the virtuous Sheikh Al-Habashi was unable to prove the correctness of the mention of pebbles or date stones in the Hadith of Sa'd and Safiyyah, and that the most he did was prove the correctness of the two Hadiths in general. I mentioned that there is no dispute regarding this amount due to the correctness of that in Juwayriyah's Hadith in Muslim.
Based on that, I say: My previous judgment that the woman in the story is Juwayriyah and that the mention of date stones in it is denounced (Munkar) still stands, due to the necessity of the non-establishment of the mention of pebbles therein and that regarding the story of Safiyyah. The words the Sheikh blackened in his treatise (p. 26 - 28) do not weaken this judgment, for it is futile speech, because it is based on what he imagined of the correctness of the mention of pebbles or date stones in the Hadith. Since this is incorrect, it is self-evident that his referred speech falls in its entirety.

Attributing to Al-Hafiz What He Did Not Say!
However, in the context of the Sheikh's referred speech came a sentence in which he attributed to Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar what he did not say. He objected to my previous judgment that it is 'based on unifying the two Hadiths, while Al-Hafiz established their difference.'
In answer to this I say: What you attributed to Al-Hafiz, you did not mention the source you relied upon for it. I am certain that this is an understanding from you based on what you imagined that Al-Hafiz's grading the Hadith Hasan means his improving/validating every sentence, indeed every word that appeared in it. The matter is not so, as previously explained with convincing proof. Supporting this is what Ibn Allan mentioned in 'Sharh al-Adhkar' under the aforementioned Hadith of Sa'd with the wording: That he entered with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, upon a woman and in front of her were date stones or pebbles. The Hadith. Ibn Allan said (1/245): 'The author of Al-Silah said: It is possible that the vague woman in the Hadith is Safiyyah... Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said: And it is possible that she is Juwayriyah.'

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
I say: This is a text from Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, may Allah have mercy on him, invalidating what the virtuous Sheikh attributed to him of the difference of the two Hadiths. If the matter were as the Sheikh narrated from him, Al-Hafiz would have asserted that the vague woman in Sa'd's Hadith is Safiyyah as explicitly stated in their two Hadiths - as preceded at the beginning of this refutation - due to the similarity of their Hadiths, Al-Hafiz strengthening them both, and the appearance of the mention of date stones in them. He would not have mentioned the possibility of her being Juwayriyah; because her Hadith does not contain the mention of date stones, and it is different from Safiyyah's Hadith in the Sheikh's opinion and in what he attributed to Al-Hafiz due to his misunderstanding!
The truth is that Al-Hafiz's statement of the mentioned possibility strongly supports what I went to in the previous article that it does not follow from Al-Hafiz's grading Safiyyah's Hadith Hasan that he validates everything mentioned in it of sentences and words. The same is said regarding his authenticating Sa'd's Hadith. Do you not see that had the matter been contrary to what I held and in accordance with what his eminence the Sheikh imagined, Al-Hafiz would have asserted or at least preferred that the woman is Safiyyah and not Juwayriyah, because the Hadith which Al-Hafiz graded Hasan contains the explicit statement that she is Safiyyah. So Al-Hafiz's refraining from asserting this to mentioning the possibility of her being Juwayriyah is clear evidence from him that he does not rely on every phrase or word appearing in a Hadith that is Hasan due to others. The reason for this was mentioned in the previous article, so let whoever wishes refer to it if he is forgetful.
The summary of speech is that if it was permissible for Al-Hafiz not to use as proof some of what came in Safiyyah's Hadith whose chain he graded Hasan, is it not permissible for me not to trust anything else that appeared in it which has nothing in others to strengthen it? Especially since in the authentic Sunnah is what contradicts it, and in the tradition of Ibn Mas'ud is what rejects it as previously explained.

The Sheikh's Ignorance of Narrator Biographies:
It seems the virtuous Sheikh did not want to limit his refutation of me to the Hadith only, but loved to extend it to refuting me regarding the tradition of Ibn Mas'ud referred to earlier. I consider that among...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...Allah's subtle plans, so that the realities of souls and their scientific values appear! His eminence said (p. 13): 'And how did he use Ibn Mas'ud's tradition as evidence; with a chain containing Al-Salt who is unknown.'
I say: This Al-Salt is Ibn Bahram as explicitly stated in the chain of the tradition itself, and the Sheikh himself quoted it from me in his treatise (p. 12). So the Sheikh's judgment of him as unknown is one of the wonders that never cease! That is because it is a statement no one absolutely preceded him in. The man is trustworthy by agreement. Ibn Abi Hatim included his biography in 'Al-Jarh wa al-Ta'dil' (2/1/438) and narrated his authentication from Ahmad and Ibn Ma'in, and from Ibn Uyaynah that he said about him: 'The most truthful of the people of Kufa.' Others also authenticated him like Al-Bukhari and others. So whoever wishes to verify that, let him consult 'Lisan al-Mizan' by Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar (3/194).
This error from the virtuous Sheikh is an example of the many examples that his eminence's knowledge is not to be trusted at all in the science of Hadith and narrator biographies. Righteousness and piety are not sufficient in it as some gullible people might think! Rather, there must be along with that alertness, intelligence, and lack of negligence. For every person occupied with this noble science is aware of what the Muhaddithin said regarding some righteous people! Ibn Adi said: 'I heard Ahmad bin Khalid say: Wahb bin Hafs was among the righteous, he stayed twenty years not speaking to anyone (!) Abu Arubah said: He used to lie excessively. And from Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan who said: "I have not seen lying in anyone more than in those attributed to goodness and asceticism"' (1).
I say: That is due to their excessive negligence and good opinion of everyone who narrates to them or quotes for them from books. I fear the Sheikh has fallen into something like this, for I have learned that he tasks some students who have no knowledge of Hadith and biographies to review some books for him in public libraries...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...then he relies on the quotations they present to him, which I hope the motive for error in them is not sectarian hostility and personal hatred, but rather ignorance and negligence only!
Furthermore, although this Al-Salt is trustworthy, he did not meet Ibn Mas'ud as I had indicated there in the article of the Hadith 'What a good reminder is the Subha.' But this indication did not please the virtuous Sheikh, so he said (p. 13 - 14): 'And what benefit does your saying (regarding Al-Salt being from the followers of the Tabi'in) provide?'
I say: I do not know how the benefit of this statement is hidden from the Sheikh while he claims knowledge of Hadith and its rules, to the point that he deluded his followers that he is the unique one of his time in this science and others! For they described him as: The scholar, the very learned, the perfect role model, gatherer of the scattered virtues, the great Muhaddith, the skilled Faqih...' And he himself approved these words in some of his treatises, despite his knowledge of his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Throw dust in the faces of praisers'!
As for the benefit of my saying this, it is not hidden from a beginner in this science, which is pointing out that the chain is disconnected between Al-Salt and Ibn Mas'ud. Because if Al-Salt is from the followers of the Tabi'in, it implies he did not hear from Ibn Mas'ud. Were it not for my saying this, I would be concealing knowledge, and giving people the illusion of the authenticity of the tradition, and this is not permissible according to us. Even if it were a proof for me, ignoring it would not occur to me.

The Sheikh's Lack of Fairness:
This is what I did regarding this tradition, pointing to its weakness. Yet despite that, his eminence the Sheikh takes me to task for not explicitly stating its weakness as I explicitly stated the weakness of the tradition of Al-Hasan which I mentioned after it there. He says in his treatise (p. 14) this context of my explicit speech in weakening Al-Hasan's tradition:

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
"'So what does it profit you, when you have admitted the weakness of its chain? And why did you not disclose the chain of the one before it?'
As for my not disclosing the previous tradition and limiting myself to indicating its weakness, it is because there is no weakened man in its chain; rather all its narrators are trustworthy. It only contains the disconnection which was explained just now. So I sufficed with explaining its disconnection alongside the trustworthiness of its men; because some scholars use the disconnected and Mursal as proof if the one sending it (Mursil) is trustworthy, as is the case in this tradition. Among these scholars are the Hanafis, some of whom adopted the Subha as if it were a Sunnah! And this great Companion denies what is less than it!
As for the benefit of my citing these two traditions while weakening their chains, it is from two aspects:
First: My using them for support regarding the denial of the Subha.
Second: Establishing the proof against the Hanafis with the tradition of Ibn Mas'ud because it is authentic according to their rules, and it is established in the Sharia that it is good to speak to people according to what they understand! Furthermore, Ibn Mas'ud's denial of counting with pebbles is established from him according to us definitively as will be explained. The Sheikh's denial of it only benefits him in revealing the reality of his knowledge of traditions! Accordingly, this tradition from Ibn Mas'ud is authentic due to others according to the Hanafis, Shafi'is, and others, because it is supported by other paths. Perhaps the benefit of this tradition has appeared to the virtuous Sheikh!
It was hoped from the Sheikh's fairness that he would appreciate our weakening of these two traditions even though they are proof for us, and that he would announce that in his treatise. And that what is between him and me of disagreement would not prevent him from that, in admission of the truth, and acting upon His saying, Exalted is He: {And do not let the hatred of a people prevent you from being just. Be just; that is nearer to righteousness}. Because he may know that few people today and before today explicitly state the weakness of their evidence which they cite, and that the concern of most is to argue with what supports their opinions of Hadiths and traditions, whether their chains are established or not. I will not take the reader far in giving examples of what I mentioned. Here is the virtuous criticizing Sheikh himself citing in his treatise (p. 11) the Hadith of Nabit Al-Ashja'i and the Hadith of Umar regarding the hanging pages, using them as evidence that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, encouraged the Companions to act upon what they did not know! Even though they are two Hadiths...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...very weak as I explained in the beginning of this refutation. Then here he is arguing to prove that the Subha was known in the era of Umar by saying (p. 10): 'Al-Suyuti extracted in "Al-Jami' Al-Kabir" Umar's approval, may Allah be pleased with him, for some who used it.'
I do not think but that the virtuous Sheikh knows that Al-Suyuti's 'Al-Jami' Al-Kabir' contains authentic narrations, weak ones, and some fabricated. So of what type is this tradition in it, O respected Sheikh? And how was it permissible for you to remain silent about it?! 'And why did you not disclose its chain?!' So when you used this tradition as evidence, you are between two matters with no third: Either you do not know its lack of establishment, or you know. In the first case, how did you use it as evidence while being ignorant of its authenticity? In the second, how was it permissible for you to remain silent about it and not explain its weakness, creating the illusion for readers by your silence that it is established! While you deny my use of Ibn Mas'ud's tradition and others despite my explanation of its weakness?! So which of us is more deserving that he be denied? The one who conceals knowledge or the one who publishes it? This disparity between us suffices you... and every vessel exudes what is in it.

The Sheikh's Ignorance of the Companions' Traditions:
I had mentioned in the article where I verified the saying regarding the fabrication of the Hadith 'What a good reminder is the Subha' that the mention of pebbles in Safiyyah's Hadith is Munkar (denounced). Then I said: 'Supporting this is Abdullah bin Mas'ud's denial, may Allah be pleased with him, upon those he saw counting with pebbles. That came from him via paths, one of which preceded. Had that been something approved by him, peace and blessings be upon him, it would not have been hidden from Ibn Mas'ud, if Allah wills.'

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
The virtuous Sheikh acknowledged this deduction of mine based on the mentioned denial of Ibn Mas'ud, but apparently he has no knowledge of this denial. For he said in his treatise (p. 28) after quoting the first part of my previous statement: 'It is said to you: With which chain do you establish this denial from Abdullah bin Mas'ud?'
I say: With a chain like a mountain in firmness and establishment. The obscurity of such a thing to him shows the rational person the extent of the Sheikh's knowledge of traditions! For this tradition which his eminence points to denying was reported via three paths from Ibn Mas'ud, in three books of Hadith known to its people! But the Muhaddith today is the one who studied the Six Books only or memorized them! Let the virtuous Sheikh check if he wishes verification: 'Kitab al-Zuhd' by Imam Ahmad (p. 358), 'Sunan al-Darimi' (1/68 Damascus edition), 'Hilyat al-Awliya' (4/380 - 381). To complete the benefit, I mention here the most authentic of these paths in chain and the most complete in text, which is in Al-Darimi via the path of Umarah bin Abi Hasan Al-Mazini who said: 'We used to sit at the door of Abdullah bin Mas'ud before the morning prayer. When he came out, we would walk with him to the mosque. Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari came to us and said: Has Abu Abdur-Rahman come out to you yet? (He is Ibn Mas'ud). We said: No. So he sat with us until he came out. When he came out, we stood up to him (1)...
foot_note: 1. (1) Note: It should be known that his saying: 'We stood up to him' (Qumna ilayhi) is not of the type of standing for another out of honor and glorification. There is a big difference between a speaker saying: 'I stood to him' (Qumtu ilayhi) and his saying: 'I stood for him' (Qumtu lahu). The first implies going to him either to receive him or to help him or for other good legitimate purposes. As for saying: 'I stood for him,' it implies standing to glorify and honor him and nothing else. This is not legitimate; rather it is disliked by the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, said: There was no person more beloved to them than the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, yet they would not stand up for him because they knew of his dislike for that. Narrated by Ahmad and Al-Bukhari in 'Al-Adab Al-Mufrad' and others with an authentic chain upon the condition of...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text: ...all together. Abu Musa said to him: O Abu Abdur-Rahman, I saw in the mosque just now a matter that I denounced, yet I did not see - praise be to Allah - anything but good. He said: What is it? He said: If you live, you will see it. He said: I saw in the mosque people in circles sitting waiting for the prayer. In every circle was a man, and in their hands were pebbles. He says: Say Takbir one hundred times, so they say Takbir one hundred times. He says: Say Tahlil one hundred times, so they say Tahlil one hundred times. He says: Say Tasbih one hundred times, so they say Tasbih one hundred times. He said: So what did you say to them? He said: I did not say anything to them, waiting for your view or waiting for your command. He said: Would you not have ordered them to count their evil deeds and guaranteed them that nothing of their good deeds would be lost? Then he went on and we went with him until he came to one of those circles and stood over them. He said: What is this that I see you doing?! They said: O Abu Abdur-Rahman, pebbles with which we count the Takbir, Tahlil, and Tasbih. He said: Then count your evil deeds, for I guarantee that nothing of your good deeds will be lost. Woe to you, O Ummah of Muhammad! How fast is your destruction! These are the companions of your Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, available in abundance. And these are his clothes not yet worn out, and his vessels not yet broken. By the One in Whose Hand is my soul, you are either upon a religion that is more guided than the religion of Muhammad, or you are openers of a door of misguidance! They said: By Allah, O Abu Abdur-Rahman, we intended nothing but good. He said: And how many intenders of good do not reach it! Indeed...
foot_note: 1. = Muslim. So his saying in this narration: 'We stood to him' means going to him. Many scholars, old and new, have neglected this difference between the two expressions. We still hear many arguing for the permissibility of standing for glorification with the likes of his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Stand to your master' (Qumu ila sayyidikum), narrated by Al-Bukhari and others. Indeed, some of them narrate the Hadith with the wording: 'For your master' (Li sayyidikum)! While it is in the Sahih as I mentioned to you: 'To your master,' meaning go to him to help him and bring him down from his mount as indicated by the cause of the Hadith's occurrence. Supporting it and cutting off dispute in it is Ahmad's narration of the Hadith with the wording 'Stand to your master and bring him down,' and its chain is strong. This is a decisive text that standing is not merely for glorification and honor but to bring him down from his mount. This is a benefit I loved not to miss explaining since its occasion arose.

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, told us: 'Indeed, a people will recite the Quran but it will not pass their collarbones.' By Allah, I do not know, perhaps most of them are from you. Then he turned away from them. Amr bin Salama said: We saw the generality of those people attacking us on the day of Nahrawan with the Kharijites.'
I say: Its chain is authentic; its men are all trustworthy men of Al-Bukhari in his Sahih except Umarah, and he is trustworthy.
I believe this explanation is sufficient to convince the Sheikh of his error in denying what I attributed to Ibn Mas'ud of his denial of counting with pebbles. After that, he must concede to me using it as evidence for the non-establishment of counting with pebbles in the Hadith of Sa'd and Safiyyah due to what was mentioned shortly before.
Furthermore, this authentic tradition from Ibn Mas'ud supports my saying which I had said in the 'Article': 'Mentioning Allah Almighty with a specific number not brought by the Wise Lawgiver is an innovation.'

Refuting the Sheikh regarding his Permitting the Restriction of Absolute Texts by his Opinion!
The virtuous Sheikh rejected this with a strange evidence I did not imagine would issue from the likes of him! He said (p. 28 - 29): 'I say: Your saying is refuted by the fact that encouragement to increase Dhikr has been authenticated, like the Hadith "Increase (1) saying La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah" without restriction to a specific limit. Al-Hafiz Al-Haythami said in "Majma' al-Zawa'id" (10/87) from Abu Said Al-Khudri from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, who said: "Increase in the enduring righteous deeds (Al-Baqiyat Al-Salihat). It was said: And what are they, O Messenger? He said: Takbir, Tahlil, Tahmid, Tasbih, and La hawla wa la quwwata illa billah." Narrated by Ahmad and Abu Ya'la, and their chain is Hasan.'
The Answer: This Hadith, if authentic - contains nothing but encouragement to increase Dhikr. This is a matter no two people differ on. So where is the proof in it that it is permissible for a Muslim to come to a Dhikr the Lawgiver did not restrict with a number, and restrict it himself?! Is this not legislation from himself which Allah the Blessed and Exalted did not authorize?
It is established in the science of Usul al-Fiqh that it is not permissible to restrict what the Lawgiver left absolute, just as it is not permissible to make absolute what He restricted; there is no difference. The absolute runs upon its absoluteness, and the restricted remains upon its restriction. Therefore, the investigating Imam Abu Ishaq Al-Shatibi said in his great book 'Al-I'tisam' (2/94):

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
"'Restriction in absolute matters whose restriction is not established by a legal proof is opinion in legislation.'
He also said (2/140): 'Chapter: Among the additional innovations (Al-Bida' Al-Idafiyyah) that approach the true (innovation) is that the origin of the worship is legitimate, except that it exits from the origin of its legitimacy [by restricting it] without evidence, under the illusion that it remains upon its absoluteness under the requirement of the evidence. That is by restricting its absoluteness by opinion or releasing its restriction.' Then he brought many useful examples to clarify that, so let whoever wishes to expand on this important research refer to them.
He also said in the Fourth Chapter on the Approach of the People of Innovation in Deduction (p. 334):
'And among them is distorting evidences from their places by taking evidence for a specific context and diverting it to another matter, creating the illusion that the two contexts are one. The explanation of that is that if the legal evidence requires a matter generally related to acts of worship - for example - and the legally responsible person performs it generally as well, such as remembering Allah, supplication, voluntary recommended acts, and similar things where it is known the Lawgiver allowed latitude, the evidence supports his action from two sides: from the side of its meaning and from the side of the righteous Salaf's action upon it. But if the legally responsible person performs that matter with a specific quality, specific time, specific place, or associated with a specific worship, and adheres to that such that it becomes imagined that the quality or time is intended legally without the evidence indicating it, while the evidence is isolated from that meaning used as proof; so if the Law recommended remembering Allah, for example, and a group adhered to gathering for it with one tongue and [one] voice or at a specific known time distinct from other times, there is nothing in the recommendation of the Law indicating this adhered specificity. Rather, there is in it what indicates the opposite. Because adherence to matters not binding legally implies understanding legislation, especially with one who is followed in public gatherings like mosques. If they are manifested this manifestation and placed in mosques like other rituals the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, placed in mosques and similar things like Adhan... they are understood without doubt as Sunnahs if not understood as obligations. So it is more appropriate that the evidence used does not cover them, so they became from this perspective innovations invented thereby.'

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
Therefore, the Jurist Ibn Abidin said in 'Al-Hashiyah' (1/778): 'Specifying Dhikr to a time not brought by the Law is not legitimate.'
There is no doubt that there is no difference between specifying Dhikr to a time not reported, and specifying it to a number not reported, for it is all from one category. Whoever does not permit that does not permit this, and vice versa, like his eminence the Sheikh, for his speech is explicit in the permissibility of restricting the absolute number. For he said later (p. 29): 'And is there any harm legally in a person persisting on a specific number of these Dhikrs not decreasing it every day...' So whoever says this, says by the permissibility of specifying these Dhikrs also to a time the Wise Lawgiver did not specify them to. This is a great negligence of what preceded from Imam Al-Shatibi and the Jurist Ibn Abidin. People's ignorance of this rule caused them to fall into many innovations, clinging to generalities into which they introduced by their opinions restrictions and forms for which Allah sent down no authority. I see fit to mention some examples of that from what scholars alerted to as innovations, as a warning to the negligent and a reminder to the believers.

Examples of Innovations the Sheikh is Obliged to Say are Legitimate Contrary to Scholars:
1 - Adhan for the two Eids.
2 - Prostration after the Salam of prayer for other than forgetfulness. 'Al-Ba'ith 'ala Inkar al-Bida' wa al-Hawadith' (p. 42), 'Al-Iqtida' by Ibn Taymiyyah (p. 140), 'Hashiyat Ibn Abidin' (1/731).
3 - Shaking hands after prayers. 'Hashiyat Ibn Abidin' (5/336), 'Al-Madkhal' (2/219).
4 - Supplication upon completing the Quran in congregation. 'Al-Fatawa al-Hindiyyah' (5/280).
5 - Gathering of people reciting one Surah, meaning with one voice. 'Al-Ba'ith 'ala Inkar al-Bida' wa al-Hawadith' (p. 58), 'Al-I'tisam' (1/34), 'Al-Muwafaqat' (3/72).

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
6 - Sending blessings on the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, upon amazement. 'Muwafaqat' (3/215), 'Al-Madkhal' (4/100).
7 - Washing (Ghusl) for the Eclipse prayer and Tawaf and similar things. 'Al-Ibda' fi Madarr al-Ibtida'' (p. 22).
8 - Adopting a specific vessel for Wudu. 'Sharh al-Tariqah al-Muhammadiyyah' (4/278).
9 - Adopting specific clothes for entering the toilet. 'Sharh al-Tariqah' (4/260 - 261).
10 - Specifying the month of Rajab with fasting. 'Al-Ba'ith' (34 - 36).
11 - Adhering to fasting the middle day of Sha'ban and standing its night. 'Al-I'tisam' (1/34).
This is a drop in the ocean of what scholars judged as innovations which are not permissible to worship by. As you see, each one of them falls under a general text, like encouragement to remember Allah Almighty, supplication, sending blessings on the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and similar acts of obedience. Yet, they exited from being obedience to innovation due to the restriction and specification that adhered to them without a legal text.
The summary of speech is that these examples and what resembles them, it is not possible for a scholar to say they are legitimate. So if the virtuous Sheikh sees claiming their approval as implied by his previous speech related to the permissibility of Dhikr with a specific unreported number, he has strayed far from correctness, and opposed the sayings of trustworthy scholars. Foremost among them is the Companion of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, Abdullah bin Mas'ud who denied restricting absolute Dhikr to an unreported number, just as he denied counting with pebbles as preceded.
Finally, I direct a question to his eminence, the answer to which from him will be the decisive factor in this issue. I say:
Is it permissible, O virtuous Sheikh, to pray the regular Sunnah prayers in mosques in congregation? If you say: It is not permissible - and this is what is thought of you - then say: Why is it not permissible when it falls under general texts like his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Allah's Hand is upon the congregation'? If you say: Because...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did not do it, we say: You spoke the truth. So it is binding upon you not to permit Dhikr with a specific number that was not reported; because the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did not do it even if it enters into the absolute text. The absolute text here does not include Dhikr described with a description that was not reported, just as the generality of his saying: 'Allah's Hand is with the congregation' did not include the congregation of Sunnah prayers due to being characterized by a description that was not reported. If you differentiate between the two matters, you are contradictory, and this is what we do not want for you nor for any Muslim.
I hope that in what preceded is what clarifies for you the path that facilitates for you returning to correctness, Allah willing, and He is the Guide.

Weakness of the Previous Hadith:
Before I finish this research, I must point out that the Hadith of Abu Said Al-Khudri whose chain the Sheikh quoted as Hasan from Al-Haythami - as preceded - is not Hasan; because it is in Al-Musnad and others from the narration of Darraj Abu Al-Samh from Abu Al-Haytham from Abu Said Al-Khudri. Darraj narrates many denounced reports (Manakir) as Al-Dhahabi said. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said: 'Truthful (Saduq), in his Hadith from Abu Al-Haytham there is weakness.'
I say: And this is from it as you see. My familiarity with the Sheikh is that he imitates Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar in disparagement and validation. So this is proof against him in his grading as Hasan a chain containing a weak narrator by Al-Hafiz's admission. But the Sheikh has no concern with verification. Rather, whenever he found a Hadith containing what refutes his opponent according to his claim, he clung to it even if it was very weak as preceded in the Hadith of the Hanging Pages. So how could he not cling to the likes of this if some graded it Hasan as in this Hadith?!
This Darraj is the owner of the Hadith 'Increase the remembrance of Allah until they say: Madman.' Discussion on it will come, Allah Almighty willing, in the articles of 'Weak Hadiths'.

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
Adherence of Some Sheikhs to the Subha Instead of Counting with Fingertips!
Then the Sheikh denied my saying: 'If there were no bad thing in the Subha except one, which is that it eliminated the Sunnah of counting with fingers or nearly did, [it would suffice in rejecting it].' He claimed it is contrary to reality. He said (p. 30): 'We still see people, most of them glorify after prayers with fingers...'
I say: If this is true, the credit for that goes to the callers to the Sunnah who encourage people to maintain it and turn away from everything that opposes it, even if some people call it a good innovation! However, this denial of the Sheikh does not apply to me because I did not intend by this statement all people, and there is nothing in my speech indicating that. Rather, I intended those whom people think are the most eager of creation for virtues, namely the Sheikhs and their likes. The proof for that is the completion of my statement which the Sheikh quoted truncated: 'For I rarely see a Sheikh counting Tasbih with fingertips.'
But the Sheikh - may Allah heal him and forgive him - proceeded in his refutation of me to take from my speech the amount that suits him so his refutation of me is valid, and turns away from the complete speech which, if the reader stood upon it, it would appear to him immediately that the Sheikh's refutation of me is invalid.
So does the Sheikh say regarding this statement of mine after quoting it completely with clarification of the intended meaning; that it is contrary to reality also? If he says that, he has been stubborn. For it is unfortunate to say: The common people believe righteousness lies in the carriers of prayer beads, due to their belief that the Subha is a manifestation of perfection. How not, when this virtuous Sheikh authors this treatise in refutation of me, one of its names (and multiplicity of names indicates the honor of the named!): 'Verification of the Clarification in Proving the Prayer Beads of the People of Faith.' Even though he was unable to prove the root which is glorifying with date stones and pebbles, so how can he not be unable to prove the branch, which is glorifying with the Subha?! Can the shadow be straight when the stick is crooked?!
Furthermore, if the virtuous Sheikh says: Most people glorify with fingertips, it is an admission from him that fewer people glorify with the Subha. So I say: Are there not among these many of the elite who...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...undertake guiding people and directing them. So why are these keen on the Subha despite containing 'leaving the better option which is counting with fingertips' as the Sheikh admitted in his treatise (p. 15). If his eminence authors a treatise supporting the Subha while it is by his admission less preferable (Mafdulah), why does he not address in it a word to those keen ones - and how do I know, perhaps the Sheikh himself is among them! - calling them to turn away from it, and advising them to hold fast to what is better, which is counting with fingertips? Or is the purpose of authoring it - as some talk about - supporting some Sheikhs who carry prayer beads by refuting Nasir al-Din who calls to reviving the Sunnah and killing innovation! I hope this is not the Sheikh's purpose in authoring it, although we insist on holding him accountable for omitting that word and advice, because the treatise without it gives a result the Sheikh does not approve - I think - which is those people continuing on the less preferable and abandoning the preferable, and this is not permissible without disagreement that I know.
Then the Sheikh said: 'And do you know anyone of the Salaf who opposed the Subha with your opposition, reaching you with an authentic chain?'
I say yes, namely Ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him. He opposed what is less than the Subha, which is counting with pebbles, and considered the doers holding onto the tail of misguidance! As we presented with an authentic chain from him. {So is there any who will remember?}?
Among the Tabi'in are those who went to the extreme in denying the Subha to the degree that they considered twisting the string for the Subha a generic evil! Is there in this what is more eloquent in denying the Subha itself?! Imam Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated in 'Al-Musannaf' (2/89/2): Hamid bin Abdul-Rahman narrated to us from Hasan from Ibrahim bin Al-Muhajir from Ibrahim who used to forbid his daughter from helping women in twisting the strings of Tasbih with which one glorifies!
I say: This is a good (Jayyid) chain, its men are all trustworthy men of Muslim. Hasan is Ibn Salih bin Salih bin Hayy Al-Thawri, and Ibrahim is Ibn Yazid Al-Nakha'i the famous Jurist graduated from the school of Imam Abu Hanifa, may Allah Almighty have mercy on him. If this was the opinion of the mentioned Imam regarding twisting the strings of the Subha, what would be his opinion regarding the Subha itself? No doubt it is a recognized evil (Munkar), indeed the severest denial.
Then he said: 'So if you do not find that, then with whom are you?'

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
I say: We have found that for you from more than one of the Salaf contrary to what you hoped. Does that convince you? Then suppose I do not know anyone from the Salaf who opposed the Subha, what is the value of that if I oppose it only because it opposes the Sunnah, and the best guidance is the guidance of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, and it is invented by agreement. Is it a condition according to the people of knowledge and reason in denying individual innovations that we have a transmission (with an authentic chain) from one of the Salaf denying them innovation by innovation? This is something no one who has smelled the scent of knowledge says! Thus the last sentence of your speech related to the Subha in your treatise falls.
To Allah is the complaint regarding wasting time and blackening paper about it, while the Sheikh agrees with us that the best is counting with fingertips as preceded repeatedly. So come, O virtuous Sheikh, let us call people to what we agreed upon, and excuse one another in what we differed on, provided the goal of everyone is eagerness to revive the Sunnah and kill innovation. May Allah have mercy on he who said:
And the best of religious matters is what was Sunnah... And the worst of matters are the newly invented innovations.

Conclusion Regarding Who is Permitted to Authenticate and Weaken:
Then the virtuous Sheikh convened a 'Conclusion' regarding 'Who has the right of authentication and weakening in Hadith, and who does not; and who is the Hafiz.' He claimed that 'Authentication and weakening are the function of the Hafiz and his specialty, no one else.' Then he quoted some words defining the Hafiz. Although these words differ and do not give a comprehensive exclusive definition of 'Al-Hafiz' - rather their difference indicates the matter is broad - what the Sheikh quoted from Al-Hafiz Al-Mizzi supports that. He said: It returns in that to the people of custom (Urf). Had there been a definition agreed upon among them, Al-Hafiz would not have referred to the people of custom, especially since they are few by his admission. Similar is the saying of Ibn Sayyid al-Nas: 'As for what is narrated from some of the early scholars saying: "We did not consider anyone a scholar of Hadith who did not write twenty thousand Hadiths from dictation," that was according to their time.'

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
In it is an indication that these definitions are specific to their times and that it is not binding on those after them to adhere to them. Whatever the case, those words agree in general that the degree of 'Al-Hafiz' is among the highest degrees specific to the Muhaddith. Therefore, it became rare among the later scholars for anyone to reach it. Sheikh Ahmad Muhammad Shakir said in 'Al-Ba'ith Al-Hathith' (p. 179): 'As for Hifz (Memorization), its trace was cut off and ended with Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar Al-Asqalani, may Allah have mercy on him. Then Al-Sakhawi and Al-Suyuti approached being Hafizs, then no one remained after them. Who knows: perhaps the Islamic nations will regain their glory, and return to their religion and sciences. No one knows the unseen except Allah. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, spoke the truth: Islam began as a stranger and will return as a stranger as it began.'
I say: But this does not prevent those specialized in the science of Sunnah from filling this deficiency by seeking help from the writings of the Hafizs themselves and their collections, especially if he gathers their sayings and researches regarding a single Hadith and the paths they mentioned for it. By that, he compensates for what he missed of memorization which used to help the early ones among the Hafizs in verification and precision. Indeed, he might even correct some of them by that. As we see in the researches of some investigators of the present era like Sheikh Ahmad Shakir the Egyptian and others like the scholars of India, may Allah bless them... However, there is nothing in those words indicating that authentication and weakening are the function of the Hafiz only.
As for the Sheikh's using as proof what he quoted (p. 36) from Al-Bulqini that he said: 'Since the Hasan is intermediate between the Sahih and the Weak according to the observer, it was something that strikes in the soul of the Hafiz...' The Sheikh said: 'In it, as you see, is the condition of Hifz (being a Hafiz) in grading Hasan and that it is from the characteristics of the Hafiz.'
I say: Understanding conditionality from this phrase is something we do not envy the Sheikh for; because the mention of 'Al-Hafiz' in it is not a restrictive constraint, evidenced by the fact that it may strike in the soul of one who...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...is below the Hafiz, like 'Al-Muhaddith' for example, and he is among those who have the right to speak on defects, death dates, and chains as Al-Subki said (1). Supporting it is that none of the scholars explicitly stated the conditionality of 'Al-Hafiz' in 'Authentication' as the Sheikh claimed. All they conditioned in that is knowledge and competence, which is what the Sheikh himself quoted from Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, that he said regarding 'Authentication': 'The most apparent to me is its permissibility for one who is enabled and whose knowledge is strong.' Similar is the saying of Al-Suyuti in the treatise 'Al-Tanqih fi Mas'alat al-Tashih': 'Sheikh Ibn Al-Salah mentioned that the door of authentication was closed in these times. Al-Nawawi opposed him, and everyone who came after him from the Hafizs up to Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar. They objected to Ibn Al-Salah in his article, and permitted authentication, and that it is not cut off nor prevented for one who has the competence for that. Then some of them refuted Ibn Al-Salah's speech saying he has no predecessor in what he said. Some refuted it saying it is based on the saying of the permissibility of the era being devoid of a Mujtahid, which is a fallen rejected saying. Some refuted it saying the people of Hadith in Ibn Al-Salah's era and after him continued on authentication. They authenticated Hadiths no one preceded them in authenticating, such as Abu Al-Hasan Ibn Al-Qattan, Al-Diya' Al-Maqdisi, Ibn Al-Mawwaq, Al-Mundhiri, Al-Dimyati, Al-Mizzi, Taqi Al-Subki, and others. Ibn Hajar prolonged the discussion in his Nukat with Ibn Al-Salah regarding that.'
Al-Hafiz Ibn Kathir said in 'Ikhtisar Ulum al-Hadith' (p. 29) essentially: 'It is permissible for the one deeply versed in this affair to proceed to judge the authenticity of much of what appeared in the Musnads, Mu'jams, Fawa'id, and Juz's of Hadith, even if a Hafiz before him did not state its authenticity, in agreement with Sheikh Al-Nawawi and contrary to Sheikh Abu Amr' (meaning Ibn Al-Salah).
Sheikh Ahmad Shakir commented on it saying:
foot_note: 1. (1) See Al-Tadrib (p. 6), and supporting it is the saying of Ibn al-Jawzi in it (p. 99).

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
"'Al-Iraqi and others refuted this statement of Ibn Al-Salah and permitted whoever is enabled and whose knowledge is strong to judge authenticity or weakness on a Hadith after examining its chain and defects, and this is the correct view. What I see is that Ibn Al-Salah went to what he went to based on the saying of preventing Ijtihad after the Imams. Just as they prohibited Ijtihad in Fiqh, Ibn Al-Salah wanted to prevent Ijtihad in Hadith. Far from it! For the saying preventing Ijtihad is a false saying; there is no proof for it from the Book or Sunnah, nor will you find a semblance of evidence for it.'
I say: The words of all these Imams agreed that the only condition for one who authenticates and weakens is to be enabled in the science of Hadith, knowing its defects and men. None of them addressed - even by hint - the condition claimed by the Sheikh. That indicates it is a fallen condition of no consideration, and that the Sheikh claims things that have nothing to do with 'Mustalah', and would that he sufficed with that, but he attaches them to the science of Mustalah and accuses his opponent of ignorance.'
What indicates to the rational person the invalidity of this condition and that no one said it before the Sheikh is the practice of scholars in all Islamic lands contrary to it, like Ibn Iraq the author of 'Tanzih al-Shari'ah al-Marfu'ah 'an al-Ahadith al-Shani'ah al-Mawdu'ah', Abdul-Ra'uf al-Munawi the author of 'Fayd al-Qadir Sharh al-Jami' al-Saghir', Abu al-Hasanat al-Lucknawi the Indian the author of many useful books, Sheikh Anwar al-Kashmiri the author of 'Fayd al-Bari 'ala Sahih al-Bukhari', Al-San'ani, Al-Shawkani, and many others in every region and city whom counting cannot encompass. Imam Al-San'ani explicitly stated what we hold in his treatise 'Irshad al-Ibad ila Taysir al-Ijtihad' saying (p. 21): 'It has been established for you by what we cited and clarified for you by what we verified that the observer in these ages has the right to authenticate, weaken, and grade Hasan, as the great Imams before him did. For the giving of your Lord was not restricted, and His extended favor is not limited to the predecessor...'.
This Al-San'ani is from the scholars of the twelfth century, and I do not think the Sheikh believes Hifz (Hafiz status) for anyone...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...after Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar except perhaps his student Al-Sakhawi or Al-Suyuti. So if Al-San'ani permitted for those in his era authentication and weakening, while there was no Hafiz in it by everyone's admission, his speech is clear evidence of the invalidity of the Sheikh's condition. Thus the desired point is proven. So may Allah have mercy on him who leaves argument and persistence.
Furthermore, if the permissibility of authentication is established for the enabled one, then weakening is also permissible for him consequently, there is no difference. Rather, perhaps this is more appropriate, for authentication necessitates knowledge of the absence of all defects explained in the Mustalah, while for weakening, standing upon a damaging defect suffices. Therefore, the one who prevented authentication permitted it, namely Abu Amr Ibn Al-Salah. He said in 'Al-Muqaddimah' (p. 18) after mentioning the leniency of Al-Hakim in his Mustadrak: 'So the best is to take a middle path regarding him, so we say: What he judged as authentic and we did not find that in it for other Imams, if it is not of the category of Sahih, it is of the category of Hasan which is used as proof and acted upon, unless a defect appears in it necessitating its weakness.'
Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi said in his explanation: 'Badr al-Din Ibn Jama'ah commented on it saying: "He should track it and judge it with what is befitting for it of Hasan, Sahih, or Weak," and this is the correct view.'
This shows that weakening is a matter agreed upon between Ibn Al-Salah and his opponents in his opinion on 'Authentication'. So it is permissible to weaken a Hadith based on the weakness of the chain. This does not contradict what the Sheikh quoted from Al-Nawawi and others (p. 37) of preventing affirming (Jazm) the weakness of a Hadith relying on the weakness of its chain, due to the possibility that it has another authentic chain. Because this only prevents affirming, due to the mentioned possibility. But if the researcher does not affirm weakness but says it based on dominant conjecture, or affirms it after repelling the mentioned possibility either by quoting a Hafiz Imam regarding the uniqueness of the weak narrator in it or after exhausting effort in investigating paths from the books of collecting Hafizs, then this is something there is no objection to. I do not imagine a rational person who has smelled the scent of...

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
...the science of Hadith saying contrary to this. Thus falls the Sheikh's saying (p. 37) following Al-Nawawi's mentioned statement: 'This is explicit in repelling what this writer did of proceeding to weaken the mentioned Hadiths without having a predecessor in that who stated it...'.
Then this speech is based on two matters, both fallen: First: Understanding Al-Nawawi's speech of preventing affirmation as meaning prevention even based on dominant conjecture, and this is an error because conjecture is below affirmation. Second: That he imitated Ibn Al-Salah in that. We have proven his error in that by explicit quotations from scholars, and whatever is built on error is error.
Among the Sheikh's oddities is that he contradicts his own words! For he said following his mentioned speech: 'What the rules of Hadith give is that the Hadith (What a good reminder is the Subha) is weak with this chain.' So he weakened the Hadith without mentioning a predecessor for him in it! So what is the difference between me in what I weaken of Hadiths and him in this, were it not for rioting?
As for the other two Hadiths regarding which the Sheikh points out that I have no predecessor in weakening, it is an accusation among his many accusations that have no reality. One of them, the Hadith of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar preceded me in weakening it. As for the other, the Hadith of Safiyyah, Al-Tirmidhi weakened it by saying 'Gharib... and its chain is not known.' All of that has been explained previously, so I was not alone in weakening them. I say this to clarify the reality. Otherwise, I do not see this condition which the Sheikh leans on in rejecting our verifications regarding weak and fabricated Hadiths - which is that we must have a predecessor in weakening - for it contradicts what the previous words of the Imams implied. Rather, I see that this condition involves suspending knowledge and freezing thought. Otherwise, what is the benefit of reading all these sciences, including the science of Mustalah al-Hadith, if the one knowing it is not permitted to judge except with what he was preceded in of correctness or weakness? Is this not contrary to what appeared in the 'Mustalah' itself?! Al-Nawawi, may Allah have mercy on him, said in 'Al-Taqrib' (p. 30):

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
'Chapter: It is not befitting to limit oneself to hearing it and writing it without knowing and understanding it. Let him identify its correctness and weakness, its jurisprudence, meanings, language, grammar, and names of its men, verifying all that...'
The truth is that the goal of the science of Hadith is knowing the Authentic from other than it, as Izz al-Din Ibn Jama'ah said. The text of his words is: 'The science of Hadith is a science of laws by which the conditions of the chain and text are known. Its subject is the chain and the text, and its goal is knowing the Authentic from other than it' (1).
The condition invented by the Sheikh destroys this supreme goal. For the researcher in the books of Sunnah comes across very many Hadiths for which he finds no one who spoke about them with authentication or weakening. So stopping then from authentication and weakening by one knowing this noble science leads to suspending the goal of the science of Hadith, as is clear and not hidden. The likeness of one who says this is only the likeness of one who claims that it is not permissible for one knowing the science of Usul al-Fiqh to give a fatwa in a new occurrence with a fatwa for which he has no predecessor! In this saying is the elimination of the goal of the science of Usul al-Fiqh, just as in the Sheikh's saying is the elimination of the goal of the science of Hadith; there is no difference.
The summary of the speech is that the condition in 'Authentication and Weakening' is only competence. As for Hifz (being a Hafiz), that is something else; if found, it is light upon light, otherwise it is not a condition as the previous words of the Imams indicated. And Allah is the Granter of success, there is no Lord but Him.

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
Conclusion of the Refutation:
I wanted to end the refutation of the virtuous Sheikh Al-Habashi in his treatise 'Al-Ta'aqub Al-Hathith' with the previous article. However, his eminence permitted the publisher of the treatise to write a word he made as a conclusion to it. Since his eminence approved him in it, he bears its moral responsibility like the rest of the treatise. So it was necessary to state our opinion regarding that word. I say:
They said: 'Benefit: Al-Suyuti mentioned in his treatise "Al-Minhah fi al-Subhah" a group who adopted the Subha or what is in its meaning.'
I say: Then they mentioned a group of them: Safiyyah, Abu Safiyyah the freed slave of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, Fatimah bint Al-Husayn, Abu Hurayrah, and others.
Our answer to that is from two aspects:
First: That none of the chains of these traditions are authentic, and there is no great benefit in prolonging the research by discussing all their individual items. It suffices us to verify the speech regarding the narrations of those whose names we quoted as examples. Otherwise, duty dictates that the Sheikh undertakes investigating the speech on them - if he could - because he is the one who used them as proof. The principle of Usul says: 'If you are quoting, then accuracy; or claiming, then evidence'! But how can the Sheikh quote only the authentic while he is ignorant of it! He declared in his treatise (p. 21) that he does not have the function of authentication. Then he exploits this ignorance, arguing with denounced Hadiths and weak traditions, while the duty upon him is to stop arguing with any of them until someone is destined for him who informs him of the authentic thereof from the weak! Therefore, our speech on some of these traditions is by way of volunteering, not obligation. So I say:
1 - Safiyyah, may Allah be pleased with her. They point by that to her previous Hadith. The publisher repeated the discussion on it. We have explained previously that the chain of her Hadith is weak, and that Al-Tirmidhi weakened it. Likewise, the chain of Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas's Hadith is weak even according to Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar, as the verification of all that preceded. Their saying:

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
"'We present in this treatise the authentication of the Hadith from Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar.'
Its answer is that Al-Hafiz only authenticated the Hadith and did not authenticate the chain. The authentication of the first does not necessitate the authentication of the Hadith's text with everything in it, like counting with pebbles, based on what we verified previously, so review it for it is a subtle matter.
2 - Abu Safiyyah: In the chain to him is the mother of Yunus bin Ubayd, and there is no mention of her in any of the biographical books. Likewise, Al-Baghawi narrated it, and via his path Ibn Shahin in 'Al-Fawa'id' (114/2), and Abu Abdullah Al-Husayn bin Yahya Al-Qattan narrated it in a portion of 'His Hadith' (170/1) from Abu Lu'bah (1) from his grandfather Baqiyyah from Abu Safiyyah. I did not know Abu Lu'bah and his grandfather Baqiyyah.
3 - Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas: The chain to him is disconnected or unknown. Ibn Sa'd narrated it in 'Al-Tabaqat Al-Kubra' (3/143) via the path of Hakim bin Al-Daylami from him. Hakim did not meet Sa'd, and Al-Hafiz mentioned him in the sixth layer, which is the one whose members are not proven to have met any of the Companions. Supporting the disconnection is that Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated it in 'Al-Musannaf' (2/89/2) from Hakim Al-Daylami from a freed maid of Sa'd from Sa'd. This maid was not named, so she is unknown.
4 - Abu Hurayrah: In the chain to him in Ibn Abi Shaybah (2/189/1) is a man from Al-Tafawah who was not named, so he is unknown.
5 - Fatimah bint Al-Husayn: The chain to her is very weak. Ibn Sa'd narrated it (8/474) from Jabir - who is Al-Ju'fi, accused of lying and used to believe in the return (Raj'ah) of Ali! - from a woman who was not named, so she is unknown.
foot_note: 1. (1) In 'Al-Isabah' by Ibn Hajar and 'Al-Minhah' by Al-Suyuti it is 'Ubayy bin Ka'b', and I did not know him either, and he is definitely not the Ansari, the great Companion.

book_title: Refutation of the 'Intensive Commentary' of Sheikh Abdullah Al-Habashi
text:
Reflect, how far the Sheikh is from scientific verification when he attributes to such virtuous people opposition to the Sunnah in our opinion, and opposition to what is best in his opinion, with such flimsy chains!
Second Aspect: Even if these traditions or some of them were authentic, we oppose them with what is authentic from Ibn Mas'ud of his denial of counting with pebbles. Its referencing and the clarification of its source, indeed its many sources which the Sheikh was ignorant of, preceded - as I explained previously. So suffice us now reminding of it, and of what is established from Imam Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i of his denial of twisting thread for the sake of the Subha, and his considering that helping in evil!
Added to that is what I came across recently from Abu Bakr bin Hafs who said: I asked Ibn Umar about glorifying with pebbles? He said: 'Does he count upon Allah?! (1) Allah counts!' Narrated by Imam Abu Zur'ah Al-Razi in his history with an authentic chain from this Abu Bakr, who is Abdullah bin Hafs bin Umar bin Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas, and he is trustworthy and a proof.
